instruction:
Here is the translation from classical Chinese to modern Chinese:

唐太宗对侍臣说：“从前初平定京城的时候，宫中美女珍宝，没有一间屋子是空的。隋炀帝还是不满足，不断征求，同时向东西征讨，穷兵黩武，百姓无法承受，最终导致亡国灭种。这些都是我亲眼所见的。所以我早晚孜孜不倦，只希望清净无为，让天下太平。于是不用徭役，年成风丰，百姓安乐。治理国家就像栽树一样，根本不摇动，那么枝叶就会繁盛。君王能清静无为，百姓怎么会不得安乐呢？”
output: Tang Taizong said to his attendant: "In the past, when (Emperor Yang of Sui) had just pacified the capital, the palace was filled with beautiful women and rare treasures, with no courtyard left empty. Yet Emperor Yang was still not satisfied. He launched military campaigns in the east and west, exhausting the country's military might and bringing untold suffering to the common people, ultimately leading to his downfall. I witnessed all of this with my own eyes. That is why I work diligently from morning to night, wishing only for peace and tranquility, which brings peace to the world. This way, corvée labor can be abolished, the grains will be abundant, and the people can live harmoniously and happily. Governing a country is like planting a tree; only when the roots are firm will the branches and leaves flourish. If the emperor can maintain tranquility, how can the people not live in peace and prosperity?"

instruction:
Here is the translation of the classical Chinese text:

Pei Ji often recounted: "When I was young, my maternal uncle was a court official with a respectable reputation. I once visited my aunt at their residence and happened to arrive just as my uncle was returning from court. He heaved a deep sigh and exclaimed, 'Who is this Cui Zhao, that everyone speaks so highly of him? He must have bribed his way to such acclaim. How can the government not be in disorder because of such corruption?' Before he could finish his words, the gatekeeper announced that Cui, the Messenger from Shou State, was waiting at the gate to pay his respects. My uncle flew into a rage and scolded the gatekeeper, threatening to whip him. After a long while, he reluctantly put on his ceremonial belt and went to greet the visitor. In a moment's notice, he urgently ordered tea to be prepared, followed by wine and food. He also instructed that the horses be fed and the servants be fed. My aunt remarked, 'Why was he so haughty earlier, and now he is so respectful?' When he entered the gate, he had a pleased expression and invited me to rest in the academic hall. Before I could descend the stairs, he took out a document from his sleeve, which turned out to be an official gift of one thousand rolls of silk presented by Zhao."
output:
During the Tang Dynasty, a man named Pei Ji once recounted a story from his childhood. When Pei Ji was young, his maternal uncle held an official position in the court and had a good reputation for being a just and honest official. One day, when Pei Ji visited his uncle, he happened to arrive just as his uncle was returning from court. His uncle heaved a deep sigh and muttered to himself, "Who is this Cui Zhao, and why do so many speak highly of him? He must have bribed his way to such praise. If things continue like this, how can our country not fall into chaos?" 

Before Pei Ji's uncle could finish his words, the gatekeeper interrupted and announced, "Lord Cui, the Governor of Shouzhou, requests an audience with you, my lord." Hearing this, Pei Ji's uncle became furious and scolded the gatekeeper. He ordered the man to drive Lord Cui away with a whip. After a long while, Lord Cui straightened his clothes and forcibly paid respects to Pei Ji's uncle. Soon after, Pei Ji's uncle hurriedly instructed the servants to serve tea to Lord Cui. Then, he ordered the preparation of a feast, and shortly after, he commanded that Lord Cui's horse be fed and his servants be given a meal.

After seeing Lord Cui off, Pei Ji's aunt asked her husband, "Why were you so arrogant at first and then so humble?" Pei Ji's uncle, with a look of benevolence on his face, walked into the house and waved for Pei Ji to leave. He said, "Go and rest in the study." As Pei Ji stepped out of the house, before he had even descended the front steps, he turned back and saw his uncle take out a piece of paper from his breast pocket. On it was written: "Gift of 1,000 bolts of coarse silk."

instruction: Why does the EU help Ukraine?

I. The EU is dominated by the US. After World War II, for security reasons, the EU essentially fell under US domination and effectively became a "pawn" in America's "global strategy". As everyone knows, the EU's real defense force is "NATO", which is controlled by the US. As such, in most areas, the EU is controlled by the US and "NATO" and must cooperate with US strategy.

II. The US has Ukraine under its control. Before the Russia-Ukraine conflict, the US successfully plotted and carried out a "color revolution" in Ukraine, overthrowing the previously pro-Russia Ukrainian President Yanukovych. The Ukrainian governments that came to power after the color revolution were obedient to the US, acting as its vassal. At the instigation of the US, Ukraine shifted from being "pro-Russia" to being "anti-Russia".

III. Ukraine itself requested to join "NATO". After Ukraine overthrew its pro-Russia regime, its foreign policy tilted entirely towards the West. Ukraine has been accommodating the US and the Western strategy to curb Russia in every way, actively seeking to join "NATO" to better integrate itself into the West. Ukraine is willing to be used by the West as a gun to target its "motherland", Russia.

IV. The West sees Ukraine as strategically valuable. Obviously, Ukraine is a major country in Europe, and it is worth it for the US and the West to "cultivate" another powerful "fighter" to defeat Russia. Since Ukraine has a certain capacity to "entangle" with Russia, in this Russia-Ukraine conflict, the EU will spare no effort to help Ukraine, aiming to thoroughly defeat Russia in this battle.

"There was a scholar who wanted to learn from a master, but the master was unwilling to teach. The master said, 'You must first read the text a hundred times.' The scholar asked, 'How can I understand the meaning by reading it a hundred times?' The master replied, 'The meaning will reveal itself after reading it a hundred times.' When asked about the meaning of "three leftovers", Dong Yu explained, "Winter is the leftover time of the year for farmers (which can be used for reading), night is the extra time of the day (which can be used for reading), and rainy days are leftover throughout the four seasons."

instruction:
Please answer the following question:

Question:
What is the nervous system, what components does it include, and what are their functions?

---
output:
Answer: The nervous system is a system that transmits and processes information. It consists of the central nervous system and the peripheral nervous system.

Central Nervous System: Comprised of the brain and spinal cord, this is the main part responsible for information processing and controlling bodily functions.

Brain: In charge of higher-level functions such as thought, consciousness, sensation, and movement.
Spinal Cord: Responsible for transmitting information and controlling the body's basic movements and reactions.

Peripheral Nervous System: Made up of neural tissue and neurons, it transmits information and connects the central nervous system to various parts of the body.

Neural Tissue: Including cranial nerves and spinal nerves, they convey information to different parts of the body.
Neurons: The basic units of the nervous system, responsible for transmitting electrical signals and information.

The functions of the nervous system include perceiving external stimuli, regulating internal functions, controlling movement, maintaining balance and coordination, as well as facilitating thought and emotion.

Question: At the end of the 18th century, which American Founding Father was hailed as "Author of America"?
output:
Answer: In the late 18th century, Thomas Paine was hailed as "The Author of the American Revolution." He was a significant figure in the American independence movement and is renowned for his contributions to independent thought. His work, "Common Sense," published in January 1776, played a crucial role in igniting the enthusiasm of the residents of the American colonies for independence. This pamphlet, widely circulated at the time, had a profound impact on advancing the independence movement.

In "Common Sense," Paine presented, in direct and understandable language, the reasons for opposing British colonial rule and called for the independence of the American colonies. His words resonated with many Americans of that time, prompting more people to support the independence movement. Hence, he earned the esteemed title of "The Author of the American Revolution" or "The Pen of the American Independence Movement."

instruction: Zilu asked: "In this case, should I proceed after hearing about it?" The Master said: "When you have father and elder brothers, how can you proceed after merely hearing about something?" Ran You asked: "In this case, should I proceed after hearing about it?" The Master said: "Proceed after hearing about it!" Gongxi Hua said: "Zilu asked whether he should proceed after hearing about it, and you said, 'When you have father and elder brothers.' Ran Geng asked the same question, and you replied, 'Proceed after hearing about it.' I am confused and dare to ask for clarification." The Master explained: "In the case of Ran Geng, as he tends to be cautious, I encouraged him to take initiative. As for Zilu, because he often acts impulsively, I advised him to be more reserved."
output: Zi Lu asked: "When you hear something, do you act on it?" Confucius said: "With a father and older brothers still alive, how could I act on everything I hear?" Ran You asked: "When you hear something, do you act on it?" Confucius said: "When I hear something, I act on it." Gongxi Hua said: "When Zhong You asked if you act on everything you hear, you said, 'With a father and older brothers, how could I?’ When Ran You asked the same question, you replied, 'When I hear something, I act on it.’ I do not understand why you gave different answers, so I dare to ask for clarification." Confucius said: "Ran You is usually cautious in his actions, so I encourage him to be bold. Zhong You, on the other hand, tends to be overly bold, so I urge him to be modest."

instruction: Why is there a rainbow after the rain?
output:
After summer rain, the sky often presents a semicircular rainbow. This phenomenon occurs due to the reflection and refraction of sunlight as it passes through water droplets in the air. 

As we know, when sunlight passes through a prism, its direction changes, and the original white light is decomposed into various colors: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, and violet. During or after rain, the air is filled with countless tiny water droplets that can refract sunlight. When sunlight passes through these droplets, not only is its direction altered, but it is also decomposed into the colors mentioned above. If the angle is right, a rainbow is formed and can be observed by us. 

The size of the water droplets in the air determines the vividness of the rainbow's colors. The larger the droplets, the more vibrant the rainbow; conversely, smaller droplets result in a paler rainbow. Summer is often accompanied by thunderstorms or showers, which usually have a limited range, meaning that it is possible to have sunshine in one place while it is raining in another. When sunlight shines on the small water droplets lingering in the air after a rain shower, a beautiful rainbow appears. 

In comparison, winter is drier, with fewer rainy days, and precipitation mostly occurs in the form of snow, which does not create rainbows. Therefore, rainbows are less commonly observed in winter. However, in very rare cases, when the atmospheric conditions are just right, a rainbow may still appear in the winter sky.

instruction:
Here is my translation of the provided Chinese text:

"Mozi had a prominent disciple named Fu Cheng, who lived in the state of Qin. Once, his son killed someone. King Huiwen of Qin said to Fu Cheng: “You are already advanced in years and have no other heirs. I have already ordered the officials not to execute your son. I hope you can accept my offer and let your son go.” Fu Cheng replied: “The rules of the Mo school state that ‘those who kill shall be put to death, and those who injure others shall be punished.’ This is to deter people from killing or injuring others. Upholding this principle is a matter of great importance for the world. Your Majesty, even though you have graciously offered to spare my son, I cannot go against the rules of the Mo school.” He declined King Huiwen's offer and insisted on carrying out the punishment himself. A son is an object of one's affection, yet Fu Cheng was willing to put aside his personal feelings to uphold a greater principle. Indeed, he can be considered a truly upright and just man."
output: The Mohists had a leader called Fuzi (Yuegaihuang), who lived in the State of Qin. His son killed someone. The King Hui of Qin said to him, "Sir, you are old and have no other son. I have ordered the officials not to kill your son. Please listen to me on this matter." Fuzi (Yuegaihuang) replied, "The Mohist law states: 'Those who kill shall be put to death; those who injure shall be punished.' This is to prohibit killing and injuring others. And the law that prohibits killing and injuring is a great justice that everyone in the world should follow. Your Majesty, although you have pardoned him and ordered the officials not to kill him, I, Fuzi (Yuegaihuang), cannot act against the Mohist law." Fuzi (Yuegaihuang) disregarded King Hui's plea and put his son to death. instruction: Why can't rabbits drink water?
output:
Whether it is animals or plants, they all need water, and the same goes for rabbits.

But why can't rabbits drink water usually? It is because their main food, vegetables, contains a lot of water, which is sufficient for their bodily needs. Also, their digestive organs are very fragile. If there is too much water in their intestines, they will suffer from enteritis and have diarrhea continuously. If treated improperly, they may even die. However, when rabbits are dehydrated, they can drink water.

instruction:
The following is a translation of the classical Chinese text:

"Qian Jinyu, an official of the Songjiang Qianzong, was of a vigorous and honest nature. In the ninth year of the Daoguang reign (1839), when the Opium War broke out, Qian was on leave to visit his family. Upon hearing the news, he immediately set out on his journey, despite his relatives and friends trying to dissuade him, saying, 'The military situation is urgent, and the outcome is uncertain. You are currently on leave, and your superior has not issued any orders for you to return. Why are you rushing into danger?' But Qian would not listen.

Upon reaching Wusong, he joined the defense of the western fort, sharing food and lodging with his soldiers and encouraging them to fight bravely. When the eastern fort fell, the enemy's bullets rained upon the western fort. Qian fearlessly commanded his troops, fighting for several hours until he was hit by three bullets in his left arm. His soldiers wept and begged him to stop, saying, 'You have an elderly mother at home, you cannot die.' But he just smiled and replied, 'How can one who has enjoyed the country's wealth and honor now flee from its troubles? Please do not worry about my mother.' Soon after, another bullet struck him in the left chest, and he fell. Even as he lay dying, he continued to shout, 'The traitorous rebels are bringing ruin to the country!' These were his final words."
output: Qian Jinyu served as a qianzong official in Songjiang County and was known for his resolute and courageous character, valuing integrity and honor. In the壬寅 (9th) year of the Daoguang Emperor's reign (1842), the Opium War broke out. Qian Jinyu, who was on leave visiting his family, immediately packed his bags upon hearing the news and set out to return. His relatives and friends tried to stop him, saying, "The war is at a critical stage, and we don't know if it will bring fortune or misfortune. You are on leave, and there are no urgent orders from your superiors. Why are you rushing back?" Qian Jinyu did not listen and, upon returning to Wusong, joined the troops guarding the West Fort. He ate, slept, and operated alongside the soldiers, encouraging each other with their determination to fight. After the fall of the East Fort, bullets and shells rained down on the West Fort. Qian Jinyu bravely commanded the battle, fighting fiercely for several hours. He was hit by three bullets in his left arm but did not retreat. The soldiers beside him wept, saying, "You have an elderly mother to take care of. You cannot die." Qian Jinyu smiled and replied, "How can one enjoy the salary of the state and then avoid danger when the state is in peril? I hope you will not worry about my mother." Soon after, a bullet struck his left chest, and he fell. Even in his dying moments, he kept shouting, "The traitors have harmed the country!"

instruction:
If students wish to serve communities lacking in medical resources, what should they do? In response to the previous question, write a paragraph that includes an answer. This can consist of 1-20 sentences. Context: 

學生若希望為缺乏醫療資源的群體服務，可以從以下幾個方面著手： 

首先，學生可以主動了解和學習相關的醫療知識和技能。他們可以參加學校或當地的醫療志願者培訓項目，或者在線學習相關的課程。通過掌握一定的醫療知識和技能，學生們可以在提供服務時更加得心應手，並能夠更加有效地幫助有需要的人。 

此外，學生們還可以積極參與社區醫療服務活動。他們可以聯繫當地的非營利組織或醫療機構，詢問是否有任何志願者機會。通過參與這些活動，學生們可以將他們的知識和技能應用於實踐，並能夠從中獲得寶貴的經驗和回報。 

再者，學生們也可以考慮發起或加入一些醫療資源的籌集活動。他們可以與同學們一起組織募捐活動，將籌集到的資金或醫療物資捐贈給有需要的社區或組織。學生們還可以利用社交媒體平台來宣傳他們的活動，並鼓勵更多的人參與進來。 

除了直接的醫療服務和資源籌集之外，學生們也可以通過教育和宣傳來提高缺乏醫療資源群體對健康問題的認識。他們可以組織講座或研討會，邀請醫療專業人士或研究人員來分享他們的知識和經驗。學生們也可以通過分發傳單或在社區中心舉辦活動等方式來傳播健康信息。 

通過採取這些舉措，學生們可以為缺乏醫療資源的群體提供切實的幫助和支持，並能夠在這個過程中獲得寶貴的技能和經驗。學生們的貢獻將能夠為這些群體的健康和福祉帶來積極的影響，並鼓勵他們繼續追求有意義的目標。
output: The University of Kansas Medical Center has three schools: the School of Medicine, the School of Nursing, and the School of Health Professions. In addition, all three schools have their own graduate programs. As of the fall semester of 2013, there were 3,349 students enrolled at KU Med. The medical center also offers a four-year teaching program at its Wichita campus and has a School of Medicine campus in Salina, Kansas, dedicated to rural healthcare.

Zong Que, styled Yuan Gan, was a native of涅阳, Nanyang. His uncle Bing (炳) was a noble and upright man who chose not to serve in the government. When Que was still young, Bing asked him about his aspirations. Que replied, "I wish to ride the wind and break through ten thousand miles of waves." Bing said, "If you do not achieve wealth and honor, you will surely bring disaster to our family." 

When his brother Mi (泌) had just married and brought his wife home, they were robbed on their first night. Que, at the age of fourteen, bravely confronted the robbers. There were more than ten of them, but they all fled in disarray and were unable to enter the house. At that time, the country was at peace, and scholars focused on literary and artistic pursuits. Bing was known for his noble character, and his sons, including Que, followed his example and were diligent in their studies. However, Que was impetuous and fond of martial arts, which is why he was not well-regarded by the locals.
output:
Zong Que, styled Yuan Gan, was a native of Nieyang in Nanyang. His uncle, Zong Bing, was a man of lofty aspirations and extensive learning who refused to serve in office. When Zong Que was still a child, Zong Bing asked him what his ambitions were when he grew up. He replied, "I wish to ride the winds and sail amidst the towering waves." Zong Bing said, "If you do not achieve great wealth and honor, you will surely bring ruin upon your family." 

On the night of Zong Que's brother Zong Mi's wedding, robbers came to raid the house. Although Zong Que was only 14 years old, he bravely fought against the robbers, scattering over a dozen of them and preventing them from entering the main house. 

During those peaceful times, esteemed literary men believed that mastering literature or pursuing a livelihood through one's skills and talents was the proper path in life. Zong Bing himself was always known for his erudition, and many of his younger brothers and nephews also shared a love for learning. However, among them, only Zong Que was willful and fond of martial arts, which is why he was not praised by his fellow townsfolk.

instruction:
Here is the translation of the provided Chinese text:

"Sun Wu occupied the lands west of Jiang, competing with the Zhongzhou states. The foundation of their success lay in the ambitious strategies of Sun Ce and Sun Quan. However, the real pillars of the state, the heroes whose loyalty ensured the survival of the kingdom, were four men: Zhou Yu, Lu Su, Lü Meng, and Lu Xun. Throughout history, generals have always been proud of their abilities and resented those who surpassed them. But these four men were different. When Sun Quan first took charge, Lu Su wanted to return north, but Zhou Yu stopped him and recommended Lu Su to Sun Quan, saying, 'Lu Su's talent is suited for assisting the times. We should seek out more talented individuals like him to achieve greatness.' Later, when Zhou Yu was on his deathbed, he wrote to Sun Quan, 'Lu Su is loyal and valiant, and he never takes matters lightly. If you choose him to succeed me, my death will not be in vain.' And so Lu Su took Zhou Yu's place as commander. When Lü Meng was the magistrate of Xunyang, Lu Su met with him and said, 'Your talent and wisdom have far surpassed those of the old Wu people.' He then paid respects to Lü Meng's mother, formed a friendship with him, and parted ways. Lü Meng went on to succeed Lu Su. When Lü Meng was stationed at Lukou and feigned illness to return home, Sun Quan asked, 'Who can replace him?' Lü Meng replied, 'Lu Xun has a profound understanding and the talent to shoulder great responsibilities. Observing his strategic thinking, I believe he is fully capable of taking on this important role, and there will be no more mistakes.' And thus Lu Xun succeeded Lü Meng. These four men took turns holding the fort at the western border for three to four decades, establishing themselves as formidable generals. They thwarted Cao Cao, Liu Bei, and Guan Yu. Although they recommended each other for their respective roles, Sun Quan entrusted them with all his heart, and this is how the kingdom of Wu thrived—it was no accident."
output: The reason why Sun Wu was able to hold on to Jiangdong and compete with the Central Plains was fundamentally due to the extraordinary talents and grand strategies of Sun Ce and Sun Quan. At that time, among the outstanding heroes of Eastern Wu, there were four people, Zhou Yu, Lu Su, Lü Meng, and Lu Xun, who were regarded as the pillars of the state. They were all ministers who were willing to share the fate of the country. However, since ancient times, most generals and commanders believed themselves to be capable and wise, fearing that others might surpass them. But the wise men mentioned above were not like that. When Sun Quan had just taken over the reign, Lu Su, a man from the north, intended to go north to the Jiangbei region to join Cao Cao. Zhou Yu stopped him and recommended Lu Su to Sun Quan, saying, "Lu Su's talent is suitable for assisting the ruler. We should seek more talented individuals like him to achieve great undertakings." Later, when Zhou Yu was on his deathbed, he wrote a letter to Sun Quan, recommending, "Lu Su is loyal and valiant, and he never takes a task lightly. If you can use him to replace me, I will have no regrets even if I die!" Thus, Lu Su succeeded Zhou Yu in leading the army. Lü Meng served as the prefect of Xuning, and when Lu Su saw him, he said, "Your talent and wisdom today are no longer the same as when you were the young boy from Wu (as Lü Meng had acquired a vast amount of knowledge by then)." Lu Su then paid a respectful visit to Lü Meng's mother, formed a friendship with him, and parted ways. Later, Lü Meng also succeeded Lu Su in commanding the army. When Lü Meng was stationed at Lukou and fell ill, he requested to resign, and Sun Quan asked, "Who can replace you?" Lü Meng replied, "Lu Xun has profound wisdom and talent capable of bearing heavy responsibilities. Observing his strategic thinking, I believe he can be entrusted with a crucial task, and he will not make any mistakes." Thus, Lu Xun succeeded Lü Meng. These four individuals took turns leading the army in the western border region for three to four decades, establishing themselves as formidable generals. They defeated Cao Cao, Liu Bei, and Guan Yu. Although they recommended each other, Sun Quan was also willing to listen to their suggestions and entrust them with important responsibilities. This was why Eastern Wu became a formidable force, and it was not a coincidence.

instruction:

The emperor ordered Feng Deyi to recommend worthy individuals, but he failed to do so for a long time. The emperor questioned him, and he replied, "It is not that I haven't been diligent, but there are simply no exceptionally talented individuals at this time." The emperor said, "A gentleman employs people according to their abilities, like using tools, and each is valued for their unique strengths. In the past, those who achieved good governance did not rely on talent from another era. The real concern is one's own inability to recognize talent, so how can one blame an entire generation of people?"
output: Emperor Tang Taizong asked Feng Deyi to recommend talented individuals, but after a long time, he did not recommend anyone. When the emperor questioned him, he replied, "It's not that I'm not doing my best, but there are simply no outstanding talents in the world today!" Emperor Taizong said, "Using people is like using tools; each has its own strengths. We should only worry about our own ability to recognize talent and not wrong the people of our time."

instruction: What is a zero trust security strategy?
output: Today's enterprises are interconnected in ways never seen before. Your systems, users, and data are always stored and operated in different environments. Simply securing the operational boundaries is no longer enough, but implementing security controls in each environment adds complexity. Either case will invariably lead to downgraded protection of the most critical assets. Zero Trust strategies always assume that threats exist and therefore always set controls in place to verify the authenticity and purpose of every user, device, and enterprise connection. To successfully execute a Zero Trust strategy, enterprises need to combine security information in some way to generate relevant control environments (device security, location, etc.) to inform and enforce verification controls.

instruction: What harm can come from eating too much ice cream?
output: Eating too much ice cream can cause the digestive system to contract from the cold. When the digestive system moves too quickly, arching and contracting, it can lead to diarrhea. This can result in the expulsion of food from the body before it has been fully digested and absorbed, preventing the body from absorbing sufficient nutrients and thus affecting health. At the same time, the addition of cream, chocolate, and other ingredients in ice cream contributes to a high-calorie content, which can easily lead to weight gain, so it is not advisable to overeat.

instruction:
Here is a simple translation of the classical Chinese text:

During the later years of his life, the Prime Minister of Qin held even more power and influence. He always had several soldiers, dressed in plain clothes and carrying clubs, standing outside his office. Whenever passersby paused to look or listen, the soldiers would immediately shout at them to move on. 

On one occasion, the Prime Minister took a day or two off due to illness, and the official in charge of the government affairs that day was left alone. The official did not dare to speak of anything else and only praised the Prime Minister's achievements and meritorious service. The next day, when the official entered the hall, the Prime Minister suddenly asked, "I heard you took a long time to report on matters yesterday. What was that about?" Terrified, the official replied, "I only spoke of Your Excellency's meritorious deeds, which are unparalleled in the world. I finished speaking and immediately retired, and did not dare to say anything else." The Prime Minister laughed and said, "Thank you very much!" It turned out that he had already instigated the officials in charge of reporting on state affairs to memorialize the emperor, and the official had just returned when the draft of the memorial and its duplicate arrived. He was so petty and cruel.
output: The power Qin Hui held eventually became even more fearsome. On regular occasions, several soldiers dressed in black and armed with clubs stood guard at the entrance of his residence. Anyone who so much as glanced at the door would be subjected to reprimand. Once, when he took a day or two off due to illness, another minister who was co-governing at the time was left alone to respond to the emperor in the court. This minister dared not speak ill of Qin Hui and could only continuously praise him in the emperor's presence. The next day, when Qin Hui arrived for the morning court session, he suddenly asked the minister, "I heard you spoke at length before the emperor yesterday?" The minister, filled with dread, replied, "I merely extolled your unparalleled virtues and achievements and then retired. I truly did not speak of anything else." Qin Hui, in a playful tone, said, "Thank you so much!" It turned out that he had already instigated officials to impeach the co-governing minister, and as soon as the latter returned home, a copy of the cabinet's impeachment against him had already been delivered to his residence. Such was the extent of Qin Hui's viciousness.

instruction: Why Red Makes Bulls Angry
output:
In the vast bullring, people are cheering and shouting. The graceful matador, dressed in a gold-trimmed red suit, waves a red cloth in his hand and dashes back and forth with the crazy bull. Those bulls, weighing hundreds to thousands of kilograms, seem to have a grudge against the red cloth, constantly charging with full force. Therefore, we naturally assume that red is the color that provokes the bull's anger. Is this really the case?

No. In fact, bulls are completely color blind. Whether you wave a red or a white cloth in front of them, it makes no difference to them. There are several reasons why bulls become enraged. First, this particular breed of bull naturally has a very irritable temperament; second, they have been confined in the bull pen for a long time and are already impatient; third, and most importantly, the matador waving the cloth in front of them makes them uncomfortable. Bulls are very sensitive to moving objects, and the waving cloth makes them think that it is an opponent, so they charge forward blindly, wanting to show their strength. However, if the opponent doesn't move, for example, if the matador poses gracefully, the bull won't even pay attention to him.

Then why do matadors use a red cloth for bullfighting? This is because red is a more stimulating color to the human eye, and the audience in the arena is more likely to get excited when they see red. When the audience is boiling, the performance effect will be particularly good. Therefore, the red cloth is not used to provoke the bull, but to entertain the audience.

instruction:
Translate the following ancient text into modern Chinese:

"The Emperor hosted a banquet at the South Palace in Luoyang and asked: 'Feudal lords and generals, none of you shall hide from me. Tell me, what is the reason I was able to gain control of the world, and why was Xiang Shi (Item Chang) unable to keep his grip on it?' Gao Qi and Wang Ling replied: 'Your Majesty sends your men to attack and occupy cities, and you reward them accordingly, sharing the benefits with the world. Xiang Yu, on the other hand, harmed those who achieved merit and doubted the wise. This is why he lost control of the world.' The Emperor said, 'You know one reason, but not the other. In terms of strategizing behind closed doors and deciding the outcome of battles from afar, I am no better than Zi Fang (Zhang Liang, whose courtesy name was Zi Fang). When it comes to stabilizing the country, comforting the common folk, providing provisions, and ensuring an uninterrupted supply of food, I am no better than Xiao He. In commanding an army of millions and guaranteeing victory in battle and success in attacks, I am no better than Han Xin. These three men are all exceptional talents, and my ability to employ them is how I was able to gain control of the world. Xiang Yu had someone like Fan Zeng but failed to utilize him, and that is why he was captured by me.'"
output: Emperor Liu Bang held a banquet at the South Palace in Luoyang and said, "Kings, dukes, and generals, do not hide it from me. Tell me the truth: why was I able to gain the world, and why did Xiang Yu lose it?" Wang Ling stood up and replied, "Your Majesty, you gained the support of others by attacking and capturing cities and territories, aligning your interests with theirs. You rewarded those with merit and trusted those with talent. On the other hand, Xiang Yu killed those with merit and doubted those with talent. This is why he lost the world." Emperor Liu Bang said, "You only see one side of the story. Inside the tent, I am not as good as Zhang Liang in strategizing and planning for battles that decide victory or defeat from a thousand miles away. In stabilizing the country, comforting the people, providing military rations, and ensuring the uninterrupted supply of food, I am not as good as Xiao He. In uniting the soldiers and winning every battle and siege, I am not as good as Han Xin. These three men are heroes, and I was able to make use of their talents, which is why I gained the world. Xiang Yu had Fan Zeng but failed to utilize his abilities, and that is why he was captured by me."

instruction:
Please answer the following question:

Question: In 19th-century art, the Indian Ocean School was an artistic movement in which country?
output:
Answer: The Indian Ocean School was a French artistic movement from the late 19th to the early 20th century, closely associated with Post-Impressionism and Pointillism. The movement's key figures included Monet (Claude Monet), Renoir (Pierre-Auguste Renoir), and Degas (Edgar Degas). Artists of the Indian Ocean School were characterized by their capture of light and color at different moments, emphasizing the representation of natural landscapes and everyday life. The name originated from an art critic who used the term "Indian Ocean School" to describe their work when reviewing Monet's paintings.

Although the Indian Ocean School was initially treated with indifference, it gradually gained wide recognition and had a profound influence on subsequent modern art. The movement was marked by themes of natural light and color variations and the use of pointillist techniques to create more vibrant images. It is considered one of the important precursors to Impressionism and modern art.

instruction:
Here is the translation of the classical Chinese text:

"Ren Mouni was only fourteen when he started his academic pursuit without a fixed teacher. He traveled far and wide in search of mentors, undeterred by any obstacles. He often said, 'If one does not strive to learn, how can they expect to achieve anything?' Sometimes he would rest under the shade of trees, building a simple hut with thatched grass, crafting brushes from reeds, and making ink by carving tree sap. On clear nights, he studied under the light of the stars and moon, and when it was dark, he tied bunches of hemp and mugwort to illuminate his path. When reading a book and coming across a passage that resonated with him, he would jot down notes on his clothing to remember it. His dedication to learning inspired his disciples, who offered him clean garments in place of the ones he had marked up. As he neared his end, he imparted these words of wisdom: 'Those who embrace learning will leave a lasting legacy, even in death; whereas those who neglect learning, though they may exist, are but walking corpses and running flesh.' "
output: Ren Mo was fourteen years old when he started his academic pursuit without a fixed teacher. Carrying his books, he traveled far and wide, braving the distance and obstacles to find mentors. He often said, "If one does not learn, how can they expect to succeed?" Sometimes, he would lean against a tree, weaving white茅into a small hut, sharpening twigs as his pen, and extracting tree sap as ink. In the evenings, he studied under the moonlight and starlight, and when night fell, he lit bundles of mugwort to illuminate his study session. When he gained insights from his readings, he would record his thoughts on his clothes, using them as a canvas for his epiphanies. His fellow students admired his diligence and took turns offering him their clean clothes in exchange. As he lay on his deathbed, he imparted these words to his students: "A person who loves learning, even in death, lives on in the hearts of others. But one who shuns learning, though alive, is no more than a walking corpse."

instruction:
The Emperor asked his attendant ministers: "Which is more difficult: founding an empire or preserving one?" Fang Xuanling replied: "In the early days of chaos, when various warlords rose up and competed for power, it was difficult to establish dominance and found an empire." Wei Zheng said: "Throughout history, emperors have gained their empires through hardship and lost them to comfort and complacency. Preserving an empire is indeed challenging!" 

The Emperor commented: "Xuanling, you and I fought together to conquer the world, facing a hundred ways to die but finding one way to live. That is why you understand the difficulties of founding an empire. As for you, Zheng, you and I work together to stabilize the world. We constantly guard against the arrogance and extravagance that wealth and honor can bring, as well as the disasters and chaos that may arise from neglect. Thus, you comprehend the challenges of preserving an empire. However, the difficulties of founding an empire are already behind us, while the challenges of preserving it lie ahead, and we must be cautious along with all of you, esteemed ministers." 

Xuanling and the others bowed and said: "Your Majesty's words are a blessing to the entire realm."
output: Emperor Taizong asked the ministers beside him, "Which is harder, founding an empire or preserving it?" Fang Xuanling replied, "Before establishing a country, one has to compete and struggle alongside various heroes and make them submit. Therefore, founding an empire is harder!" Wei Zheng said, "Since ancient times, emperors have gained the world in adversity and lost it in comfort. Preserving an empire is even more difficult!" Emperor Taizong said, "Xuanling and I fought side by side to establish this dynasty, risking our lives together. So, he understands the hardships of founding an empire. Wei Zheng and I stabilized the world together, often worrying that wealth and honor would lead to arrogance and extravagance, causing chaos and disorder. That is why he knows the challenges of preserving an empire. However, the difficulties of founding an empire are now in the past, and we should carefully address the challenges of preserving it." Xuanling and the others bowed and said, "Your Majesty's words are a blessing for the country and its people!"

instruction:
A person's talents and abilities are rarely complete, and if he has strengths, he will surely have weaknesses. If we make use of people's strengths to compensate for their weaknesses, then there will be no one in the world who is not useful; if we reject people because of their weaknesses and ignore their strengths, then there will be no one in the world who is not abandoned. Moreover, people's emotions are influenced by likes and dislikes, and their interests are diverse. Even if someone is as wise as Yi Yin or King Zhou, or as virtuous as Mozi or Yang Zhu, if we seek to judge them through public opinion, who can avoid criticism and slander? 

Once, Zigong asked Confucius: "What do you think of a person whom everyone in his hometown likes?" Confucius replied: "It's not necessarily a good thing." "What about someone whom everyone in his hometown dislikes?" Confucius said: "It's not necessarily a bad thing either. It's better to be liked by the virtuous people in his hometown and disliked by the unvirtuous ones." This is because the intentions of a gentleman and a petty person are bound to be opposite, just as a petty person dislikes a gentleman, so does a gentleman dislike a petty person. If we want to understand their true nature, we should carefully examine the foundation of what we hear. If we listen only to gentlemen, then the words of petty people will be disregarded; if we listen to petty people, then the teachings of gentlemen will be lost.
output:
A person's talent and virtue, from ancient times to the present, have rarely been fully possessed by anyone. If one employs a person based on their strengths and then supplements their weaknesses, then there is no one in the world who cannot be employed. If one only sees the shortcomings and disregards the strengths, then there will be no one suitable for employment. Moreover, people's emotions are divided by love and hate, and their interests vary. If we look for perfection in sages like Yi Yin and Zhou Gong, or expect perfect virtue in wise men like Mozi and Yang Zhu, who among them can escape ridicule? 

Previously, Zi Gong asked Confucius: "What should be done if one is liked by everyone in a village?" Confucius replied, "It is uncertain." "What if one is disliked by everyone in the village?" "It is still uncertain. One should not assume that a person is good just because the villagers like him, nor should one hate him just because they dislike him." This is because the actions of good and bad people will surely differ. Just as a petty person hates a gentleman, so too does a good person hate an evil one. One must investigate the situation carefully. If we listen to the words of gentlemen, then the ways of petty people will cease. If we listen to the words of petty individuals, then the ways of gentlemen will vanish.

instruction: What is "one country, two systems"?
output: "One country, two systems" is a constitutional principle proposed by Deng Xiaoping, the second-generation leader of China, in the 1980s to achieve the goal of unification. It was first introduced to address the cross-Strait relations and was later applied to Hong Kong and Macau, which were formerly British and Portuguese colonies, respectively. "One country, two systems" refers to "one country, two different social systems." Under this principle, Hong Kong and Macau can retain their capitalist economic systems and socio-political systems, while the Chinese mainland continues to practice socialism with Chinese characteristics. Hong Kong and Macau may maintain their own political systems, legal systems, economic policies, financial affairs, governance systems, and external relations for 50 years.

instruction: Why shouldn't you lick your teeth when they're loose?
output: When you are losing your baby teeth, if you constantly use your tongue to lick your teeth, your new teeth will not grow straight in your gums. If your teeth grow crooked and misaligned, with some higher and some lower, they will not only look unsightly, but food residue will also be more likely to get stuck in the gaps, making it difficult to clean thoroughly. This can easily lead to tooth decay or other dental problems.

instruction:
Please answer the following question:

Question:
What is the cardiovascular system, which organs does it include and what are their functions?

Answer:
The cardiovascular system, also known as the circulatory system, is an organ system that delivers nutrients, oxygen, and hormones to the body's cells, and removes waste products. It comprises the heart, blood vessels (including arteries, veins, and capillaries), and blood. 

The heart is a muscular organ about the size of a fist, located between the lungs in the chest cavity. It pumps blood continuously through the network of blood vessels, ensuring a constant supply of oxygen and nutrients to all parts of the body. The heart has four chambers: the right atrium, the right ventricle, the left atrium, and the left ventricMultiplier. Blood flows from the body and enters the right atrium, then moves to the right ventricle, which pumps it to the lungs via the pulmonary artery. In the lungs, carbon dioxide is exchanged for oxygen. Oxygenated blood returns to the left atrium, from where it passes to the left ventricle, which then pumps the oxygen-rich blood through the aorta to be distributed to the body. 

The blood vessels form a complex network that carries blood to and from the heart, as well as between different organs and tissues. Arteries carry oxygenated blood away from the heart, veins carry blood back to the heart, and capillaries are tiny vessels that connect arteries and veins and enable the exchange of water, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the body's cells. 

In summary, the cardiovascular system is vital for maintaining the body's overall health and homeostasis, ensuring the delivery of essential nutrients and oxygen to cells and removing waste products. The proper functioning of this system is crucial for the well-being and survival of an individual.
output:
Answer:
The cardiovascular system is the system responsible for transporting blood and supplying oxygen and nutrients to tissues throughout the body. It includes the heart, blood vessels, and blood.

As a person, one must learn, and learning naturally requires asking questions.

output: In terms of diplomacy, a salute is a display of respect by firing cannons when an esteemed guest arrives. Firing 21 cannons is the highest salute, reserved for esteemed guests such as heads of state, government leaders, and other dignitaries. Firing 19 cannons is to welcome foreign guests of the rank of minister or general. Firing 17 or 15 cannons, among other numbers, is to welcome foreign guests of a lower rank. It is customary to fire an odd number of cannons in a salute.

instruction:
The destruction of the six states was not because their soldiers were weak or they were poor at fighting, but because they bribed Qin. Bribing Qin weakens your strength and leads to destruction. Some may ask: "Did the six states all bribe Qin?" No, but those that did not bribe Qin were destroyed by those that did, as they lost strong support and could not stand alone. Thus, we can say that the calamity lay in bribing Qin.

Apart from its military conquests, Qin gained small cities in some cases and large cities in others. Comparing what Qin gained through bribery to what it gained through victory in battle, the former was actually a hundred times more. Comparing what the feudal lords lost through bribery to what they lost through defeat in battle, the latter was also a hundred times more. Thus, what Qin greatly desired and what the feudal lords greatly feared certainly did not lie in battle. 

Recalling their ancestors who endured frost and dew and cut through brambles and thorns to gain a small piece of land, their descendants do not value it very much and simply give it away to others, treating it like discarded weeds. Today they cede five cities, and tomorrow they cede ten cities, and only then can they sleep soundly for a night. When they wake up and look at their borders, the Qin army has arrived again. Thus, the land of the feudal lords is limited, while Qin's greed is insatiable. The more they serve it, the more demands it makes, and the more it encroaches. Therefore, without even fighting, the strong and weak, and the victorious and defeated, have already been decided. When it came to the five states' destruction, it was only logical. As the old saying goes: "Giving land to Qin to appease it is like carrying firewood to put out a fire. If the firewood does not run out, the fire will not go out." This saying hits the mark.

The people of Qi never bribed Qin and eventually followed the five states into destruction. Why? Because they allied with Qin and did not aid the five states. Once the five states were destroyed, Qi also could not escape its fate. The rulers of Yan and Zhao were the first to have a far-sighted strategy, able to defend their territory, and they did not bribe Qin out of a sense of righteousness. Thus, although Yan was a small state, it was the last to perish, and this was the effectiveness of their military strategy. When it came to using Jing Ke to assassinate Qin Shi Huang, they only hastened their destruction. Zhao fought five battles with Qin, losing two and winning three. Later, Qin attacked Zhao twice, but General Li Mu repulsed them both times. When Li Mu was executed due to slander, Handan became a county, and it was a pity that his use of the military was not continued. Moreover, Yan and Zhao were situated at a time when Qin was on the verge of destroying all the states, and they could be described as having limited resources and being in a perilous situation. Their defeat and destruction were truly unavoidable. If only the three states had each cherished their territory, if the people of Qi had not attached themselves to Qin, if the assassins had not been sent, and if the capable generals had still been there, then the odds of victory or defeat and the principles of existence or destruction would have been comparable to Qin's, and it may not have been easy to determine the outcome.

Alas! If the land that was used to bribe Qin had been used to seal the titles of the wise and capable ministers in the world, and if the hearts that served Qin had been used to honor the extraordinary talents in the world, and if their combined strength had been directed westward, then I fear that the people of Qin would not have been able to swallow their food. What a pity! With such power, they were intimidated by Qin's accumulated might, gradually losing land and marching towards destruction. Oh, rulers of the states, never let yourselves be intimidated by accumulated might!

The six states and Qin were all feudal lords, and their power was weaker than that of Qin, but they still had the power to not bribe and defeat it. If you use the vastness of the world and follow the story of the six states' destruction, then you are even lower than the six states.
output:
The demise of the Six States was not because their weapons were not sharp or they fought poorly. The problem lay in bribing Qin with land. Bribing Qin with land weakened their own power, and this was the reason for their downfall. Some may ask, "Did all six states perish one after the other simply because they bribed Qin?" (The answer is) "Those states that did not bribe Qin perished because of those that did. The reason was that the non-bribing states lost their strong external support and could not survive on their own. Thus, we say the problem was bribing Qin."

Qin not only seized land through warfare but also received bribes from the feudal lords. The smaller bribes resulted in townships, while the larger ones yielded cities. Comparing the land Qin obtained through bribes to that gained through victories over other states, the former was actually a hundred times greater. The land lost by the feudal lords of the Six States through bribes far exceeded that lost in defeat, also by a hundredfold. So, what Qin desired most and what the Six States feared most had nothing to do with war. Thinking of their forefathers who braved the cold and toiled through the rain, hacking through brambles and thorns to gain a tiny bit of land, only for their descendants to squander it all by giving it away, treating it as worthless as discarded grass—today, they cede five cities, and tomorrow, ten, only then can they sleep soundly for a night. But upon waking the next day and looking around, they see Qin's armies again. Since this is the case, with the finite land of the feudal lords and the insatiable greed of the violent Qin state, the more the lords give, the more urgently Qin invades. Thus, without resorting to war, the balance of power and the outcome of victory or defeat have already been decided. When it reaches the point of annihilation, the logic is as such. The ancients said, "Using land to serve Qin is like carrying firewood to put out a fire. As long as the firewood doesn't burn up, the fire won't go out." This saying is very true.

Qi never bribed Qin, yet it ultimately perished along with the Five States. Why? Because it befriended Qin and did not aid the other five states. With the Five States gone, Qi could not escape its fate. The rulers of Yan and Zhao initially had far-sighted strategies, able to defend their territories, uphold justice, and refrain from bribing Qin. Thus, although Yan was a small state, it perished later, and this was the effect of resisting Qin by force. Later, when Crown Prince Dan of Yan sent Jing Ke to assassinate the King of Qin, this act invited calamity. Zhao once fought five battles with Qin, losing twice and winning thrice. Later, Qin attacked Zhao twice, but (Zhao's general) Li Mu repeatedly repulsed Qin's offensives. Eventually, Li Mu was framed and killed, and Handan (Zhao's capital) became a Qin district. It was unfortunate that Zhao, in resisting Qin with force, could not hold out in the end. Moreover, Yan and Zhao were in a situation where Qin had almost wiped out the other states, and one could say they were intellectually exhausted, their states isolated and imperiled. Their defeat and destruction were indeed unavoidable. If Han, Wei, and Chu cherished their territories, if Qi did not side with Qin, if the assassin (from Yan) had not gone (to kill the King of Qin), and if the capable general Li Mu had lived, then the fortunes of victory and defeat, the principles of existence and destruction—when compared with Qin—may not have been easily measurable.

Alas! (If the feudal lords) had used the land they bribed Qin with to reward the strategists of the world, and with the heart they served Qin, treated the exceptional talents of the world, uniting as one and facing west (toward Qin), then I fear the people of Qin wouldn't even be able to swallow their food. How lamentable! With such advantageous circumstances, they were coerced by Qin's long-established might, ceding land day after day, month after month, until they met their demise. Oh, rulers of states, do not be coerced by long-established might!

The Six States and Qin were all feudal states, and although their power was weaker than Qin's, they still had the advantage of being able to defeat Qin without bribing it. If one relies on a vast state yet follows the precedent of the Six States' downfall, one is even worse off than the Six States.

instruction:
Here is the translation of the passage from classical Chinese to modern Chinese:

有一个叫何岳的秀才，他的号是畏斋。他曾经在一次夜行的途中捡到了二百多两银子，但他不敢告诉家人，担心他们会劝说他留住这笔钱。第二天早上，他带着银子来到捡到它们的地方，看到一个人找了过来，询问银子的数量和封识，都和他所写的一模一样，于是他把银子还给了对方。那个人想要分一些银子作为感谢，畏斋说：“捡到银子却没有人知道，这些本来都是我的东西，我为什么要利己地拿走这几两银子呢？”那个人非常感谢就离开了。

何岳也曾经在宦官家教书，那位宦官有事进京，寄存了一箱子在何岳家，里面有几百两银子，说：“等我来日再来取。”几年过去了，完全没有音信，听说他的侄子因为其他事情来到南方，但不是为了取那箱银子。于是宦官托人转寄了那箱银子。何岳只是一个贫穷的秀才，捡到银子还能勉强理解；但寄存银子多年，心里却从不为所动，这就远远超出了普通人能做到的范围了！
output:
The scholar He Yue once found more than 200 taels of silver while walking at night. He did not dare to tell his family about it, worrying that they would advise him to keep the silver. The next morning, he returned to the place where he had found the silver and saw a man searching for something. He asked the man about the amount of silver and the seal, and the man's answers matched. So, he returned the silver to the man. The man wanted to give him a portion of the silver as a token of gratitude, but He Yue said, "I found the silver, and no one else knows about it. All the silver could have been mine, so why would I be tempted by these few taels?" The man thanked him and left.

When He Yue was teaching at an official's home, the official sometimes had to go to the capital and left a box with He Yue, containing hundreds of taels of silver. The official told He Yue to keep it safe and retrieve it when he returned. However, the official would be away for years at a time, with no news. When He Yue heard that the official's nephew was coming to the south for another matter, he entrusted the box to the nephew to return it to the official in the capital.

He Yue, a poor scholar, demonstrated his integrity by returning the silver he found. His lack of greed in the short term is commendable, but what is even more remarkable is that he did not give in to temptation even though the official left the silver in his care for years. His noble character far surpasses that of ordinary people!

At that time, he had to go out of town for something, and unexpectedly met Fu Qin, who was also staying at the same inn. At first, they did not recognize each other. So he went up to Fu Qin's carriage and said, "I have long wanted to annotate the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, but I have not yet finished. instruction: Why is IAM important?
output:
Identity and Access Management (IAM for short) is a security protocol that enables the right entities (people or things) to use the right resources (applications or data) when needed, without interfering with the devices they want to use. IAM consists of systems and processes that allow IT administrators to assign a single digital identity to each entity, authenticate them at login, authorize access to designated resources, and monitor and manage these identities throughout their lifecycle.

IAM is no longer just for employees. Organizations must be able to provide secure access for contractors and business partners, remote and mobile users, and customers. With digital transformation, identities are also being assigned to Internet of Things (IoT) devices, robots, and code snippets such as APIs or microservices. Multi-cloud hybrid IT environments and Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) solutions further complicate the IAM landscape.

As it sits between users and critical enterprise assets, identity and access management is a key component of any enterprise security plan. It helps prevent user credential leaks and easily guessable passwords, which are common network entry points for criminal hackers looking to inject ransomware or steal data.

When implemented properly, IAM helps ensure business productivity and the smooth running of digital systems. Employees can work seamlessly wherever they are, while centralized management ensures they only access specific resources necessary for their work. Opening up systems to customers, contractors, and suppliers can increase efficiency and reduce costs.

instruction: Why is there more ice in the Antarctic than in the Arctic?
output:
The Antarctic region is home to a large landmass known as the "seventh continent" of the world, covering an area of approximately 14 million square meters. The land has a low heat storage capacity, causing the heat gained during the summer to quickly radiate away, resulting in an abundance of ice. 

The continental glaciers have also formed numerous ice barriers and icebergs. 

In the Arctic region, the Arctic Ocean occupies a significant area of around 1,310 square kilometers. Water has a high heat capacity, allowing it to absorb a considerable amount of heat and release it slowly, which explains the lesser amount of ice compared to the Antarctic.

instruction: Why doesn't the stomach digest itself?
output:
The stomach is able to secrete hydrochloric acid and pepsin to digest proteins in meat and turn them into nutrients for the human body. Since the stomach itself is also made up of proteins, why doesn't it digest itself?

Scientists have found that the stomach can also secrete a viscous, gelatinous mucus that covers the inner surface of the stomach, preventing corrosion by hydrochloric acid and pepsin. In addition, the epithelial cells of the mucous membrane on the inner surface of the stomach are arranged in a tightly packed, special structure, forming a physiological barrier. This barrier can block the intrusion of hydrochloric acid. As long as the two "defenses", the mucus membrane and the physiological barrier of the gastric mucous membrane, are intact, they can resist self-decomposition.

instruction: Why are white animals rare?
output:
Because, aside from the North and South Poles, white is not the natural color of the environment. If an animal is white, it is easily preyed upon by predators. According to the theory of evolution, natural selection would result in fewer white animals.

However, in the polar regions where white is the dominant environmental color, white becomes a form of camouflage. As a result of natural selection, there are more white animals in these regions.

instruction: Why did the Japanese military launch a surprise attack on Pearl Harbor?
output:
There are many speculations about the reason for Japan's surprise attack on Pearl Harbor. The materials discovered after the war show that the Pearl Harbor incident was actually an energy war, or more precisely, an extreme measure taken by Japan in response to the oil embargo imposed by the United States.

The United States hoped to curb Japan by cutting off its energy supply
Oil, as an important strategic resource, has always been closely tied to wars. As an island country with limited resources, Japan's shortage of energy became a fatal weakness in its quest for world domination. In the late 1930s, 90% of Japan's domestic oil demand was met by imports, 85% of which came from the United States, the largest oil exporter at that time.
Before the surprise attack on Pearl Harbor, Japan had been waging a four-year war on the Asian continent, aiming to plunder the abundant natural resources in the region.

Japan's aggression against Asian countries obviously posed a threat to the United States' interests in the Far East. However, isolationism in the United States also put the Roosevelt administration in a dilemma. Isolationists believed that the country should neither provide military aid to nations under the threat of war nor impose economic sanctions on aggressor states. Moreover, under pressure from the British government and the US Congress, President Roosevelt was advised not to engage in military conflict with Japan in the Pacific, as it would hinder future aid to allies and divert public attention away from Hitler's aggression plans.

In July 1940, the United States passed the Export Control Act, which provided President Roosevelt with a pretext to retaliate against Japan's rampant expansion in Asia. When the Japanese military began invading northern Indochina in September 1940, President Roosevelt used this act to impose an embargo on scrap iron and steel exports to Japan. Soon after, he also banned the export of aviation fuel and lubricants, stating that these materials could only be exported to the United Kingdom and other Western Hemisphere countries.

At the same time, the Japanese were also pondering and began to reevaluate their foreign policy. The military, especially the high-ranking officers, had been exerting a detrimental influence on diplomacy since the establishment of the puppet state of Manchukuo in Northeast China. The military leadership was also the main force advocating for an alliance with Germany and Italy, and they supported prolonging the war in China and further advancing into southern Asia to realize their imperial dream of energy self-sufficiency. In the summer of 1940, Duke Konoe Fumimaro became the Prime Minister of Japan. While the Konoe cabinet tacitly approved the military's further expansion in Asia, it also worked towards reconciliation with the United States. However, by authorizing the occupation of French Indochinese bases and signing the Tripartite Pact with Germany and Italy, the Konoe cabinet left President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull with no room for concessions in the negotiations.

In the winter of 1940, Britain's transatlantic energy supply lines suffered devastating attacks from German submarines, which heightened US concerns about the situation. In April 1941, Germany occupied Yugoslavia and Greece and inflicted heavy casualties on the British military in Crete and North Africa. President Roosevelt had no choice but to extend the US neutrality zone in the Atlantic and further east to prevent a Hitler invasion. In May, President Roosevelt announced a strengthening of submarine tracking and escort efforts in the region and redeployed the Pacific Fleet to reinforce the Atlantic Fleet. As a result, the United States declared a state of national emergency, and Washington placed aiding Britain as an undisputed priority.

instruction:

"The Xiongnu realized that Wu could not be coerced and reported this to the Chanyu. The Chanyu became even more determined to subdue him. He imprisoned Wu in a large pit, denying him food and water. It snowed, and Wu chewed on the snow together with the felt of his hat, swallowing them. Several days passed, yet he did not die. The Xiongnu considered him a divine being. They exiled Wu to a deserted place by the northern sea and made him tend rams. Only when the rams had given birth to lambs was Wu allowed to return. His officials, including Chang Hui, were separated from him and sent to different places. When Wu arrived at the seaside, his rations did not arrive. The Chanyu wanted to make him surrender even more, so he imprisoned Su Wu in an underground cellar and did not give him food or water. When it snowed, Su Wu chewed on the snow as he lay down, swallowing it together with the wool of his felt blanket to fill his stomach, and managed to survive for several days. The Xiongnu found this miraculous, so they moved Su Wu to a deserted place by the North Sea, made him herd rams, and told him that he would only be allowed to return to Han when the rams gave birth to lambs. At the same time, they relocated his subordinates and accompanying personnel, including Chang Hui, to other places. After Su Wu was moved to the North Sea, he could not get any grain shipments and could only dig up and eat the wild fruits stored by field mice. 墨子子墨子说：“仁人做事的准则，一定是兴天下之利，除天下之害。”那么，什么是天下的利益？什么是天下的祸害呢？墨子说：“现在如果国与国之间互相攻伐，家族与家族之间互相篡夺，人与人之间互相残杀，君臣之间不忠诚，父子之间不孝顺，兄弟之间不和睦，这些就是天下的祸害。”

那么，观察这些祸害，又是什么原因造成的呢？是因为不相爱吗？墨子说：“是由于不相爱造成的。现在诸侯只知道爱自己的国家，不爱别的国家，所以不顾惜举起自己的国家去攻打别的国家。现在一家之主只知道爱自己的家庭，不爱别的家庭，所以不顾惜举起自己的家庭去篡夺别的家庭。现在人只知道爱自己，不爱别人，所以不顾惜举起自己去残害别人。因此，诸侯不相爱，就一定会野战；一家之主不相爱，就一定会互相篡夺；人与人不相爱，就一定会互相残杀；君臣不相爱，就不忠诚；父子不相爱，就不孝顺；兄弟不相爱，就不和睦。天下的人都不相爱，强势的就会欺压弱小的，富有的就会侮辱贫穷的，有权势的就会傲视卑微的，欺诈的就会欺骗愚直的。凡是天下的祸患、篡夺、怨恨，之所以产生，都是由于不相爱造成的，所以仁人批判它。”

既然批判了它，又该用什么来取代它呢？墨子说：“用兼相爱、交相利的法则来取代它。”那么，什么是兼相爱、交相利的法则呢？墨子说：“看别人的国家就像看自己的国家，看别人的家庭就像看自己的家庭，看别人的身体就像看自己的身体。因此，诸侯互相爱护，就不会野战；一家之主互相爱护，就不会互相篡夺；人与人互相爱护，就不会互相残杀；君臣互相爱护，就忠诚；父子互相爱护，就孝顺；兄弟互相爱护，就和睦。天下的人都互相爱护，强势的不会欺压弱小的，众多的不会劫掠少数的，富有的不会侮辱贫穷的，有权势的不会傲视卑微的，欺诈的不会欺骗愚直的。凡是天下的祸患、篡夺、怨恨，都可以避免，都是因为互相爱护而产生的，所以仁人赞誉它。”

然而，现在天下的士君子说：“兼爱确实很好。虽然如此，天下的人们很难改变旧有的习惯啊！”墨子说：“天下的士君子只是没有认识到它的好处，没有辨明其中的道理罢了。现在像攻打城池、野战、杀身成仁这些，都是天下百姓所难做到的，如果君王喜欢这些行为，那么士众也能做到。何况兼相爱、交相利与这些行为不同！爱别人的人，别人也会随之去爱他；利于别人的人，别人也会随之去利于他；害别人的人，别人也会随之去害他；恶意对待别人的人，别人也会随之恶意对待他。这有什么难的呢？只是君王不把它当作政治准则，士人不把它当作行为准则罢了。从前，晋文公喜欢士人穿破旧的衣服，所以文公的臣子们都穿牂羊皮做的皮裘，用皮革做带剑的腰带，头戴白绸帽，入宫拜见君王，出宫后在朝廷上行走。这是为什么呢？因为君王喜欢这样的行为，所以臣子们也这样做。从前，楚灵王喜欢士人吃得少，所以灵王的臣子们都以一顿饭为食，呼吸一下才系上腰带，扶着墙才站起来。一年多以后，朝堂上呈现出黧黑的颜色。这是为什么呢？因为君王喜欢这样的行为，所以臣子们也能这样做。从前，越王勾践喜欢士人的勇敢，训练他的臣子，私下让人放火烧船，考验他的臣子们，说：‘越国的宝物全部在这里！’越王亲自擂鼓，激励他的臣子们前进。臣子们听到鼓声，就拼命地冲向火中，左右有百余人丧命，越王敲响金器命令他们退下。”所以墨子说：“像吃得少、穿破旧的衣服、杀身成仁这些行为，都是天下百姓所难做到的，如果君王喜欢这些行为，那么百姓也能做到，何况兼相爱、交相利与这些行为是不同的。爱别人的人，别人也会爱他；利于别人的人，别人也会利于他；害别人的人，别人也会害他；恶意对待别人的人，别人也会恶意对待他。这有什么难的呢？只是士人不把它当作政治准则，也不把它当作行为准则罢了。”
output:
Mozi said, "The principle by which a benevolent person handles affairs must be to benefit the world and eliminate harm, using this principle to handle affairs." Since this is the case, then what is beneficial to the world, and what is harmful to the world? Mozi said: "Now, when countries attack each other, families plunder each other, people harm each other, rulers and ministers do not benefit and be loyal to each other, fathers and sons do not love and respect each other, and brothers are not harmonious and united, these are all harmful to the world."

Since this is the case, then what are these public hazards caused by? Are they caused by not loving each other? Mozi said: "They are caused by not loving each other." Nowadays, the feudal lords only know how to love their own country and not those of others, so they unscrupulously use their country's power to attack others. The current family patriarchs only know how to love their own family and not others, so they unscrupulously use their family's power to plunder others. People nowadays only know how to love themselves and not others, so they unscrupulously use all their might to harm others. Therefore, when feudal lords do not love each other, they will inevitably engage in warfare; when family patriarchs do not love each other, they will inevitably plunder one another; when people do not love each other, they will inevitably harm one another; when rulers do not love their ministers, they will inevitably fail to benefit and be loyal to each other; when fathers do not love their sons, they will inevitably fail to love and respect each other; when brothers do not love each other, they will inevitably fail to be harmonious and united. When people in the world do not love each other, the strong will inevitably control the weak, the wealthy will inevitably bully the poor, the noble will inevitably look down on the humble, and the cunning will inevitably deceive the foolish. All the disasters, plunder, grievances, and resentments in the world arise because people do not love each other. Therefore, the benevolent consider it wrong.

Since it is considered wrong for people not to love each other, then what should be used to change this? Mozi said: "Use the method of everyone loving each other and mutually benefiting to change it." Since this is so, how should everyone love each other and mutually benefit? Mozi said: "Treat other people's countries as your own, treat other people's families as your own, and treat other people's bodies as your own." Therefore, when feudal lords love each other, they will not engage in warfare; when family patriarchs love each other, they will not plunder each other; when people love each other, they will not harm each other; when rulers and ministers love each other, they will benefit and be loyal to each other; when fathers and sons love each other, they will love and respect each other; when brothers love each other, they will be harmonious and united. When people in the world love each other, the strong will not control the weak, the majority will not force the minority, the wealthy will not bully the poor, the noble will not look down on the humble, and the cunning will not deceive the foolish. All the disasters, plunder, grievances, and resentments in the world can be prevented because people love each other. Therefore, the benevolent praise it.

However, the scholars and gentlemen of the world now say: "Yes, universal love is indeed good. Even so, it is a difficult and roundabout affair in the world." Mozi said: "The scholars and gentlemen of the world only fail to discern the benefits of universal love and the reasons for it. Now, for example, attacking cities and engaging in warfare, or starving oneself to death for the sake of fame, these are all things that the common people of the world find difficult to do. But if the ruler likes it, then the scholars can do it. In comparison, universal love and mutual benefit are entirely different (good things). Those who love others will be loved by others in return; those who benefit others will be benefited by others in return; those who hate others will be hated by others in return; and those who harm others will be harmed by others in return. What is difficult about practicing this universal love? It is only because those in superior positions do not use it in governing, and the scholars do not put it into practice." In the past, Jin Wen Gong liked scholars to wear poor clothes, so the scholars under Wen Gong wore sheepskin coats, tied their swords with ox leather, and wore hats made of boiled silk. They could enter the palace or go to court dressed like this. Why was this? Because the ruler liked it, the subjects did so. In the past, King Ling of Chu liked slender waists, so the subjects of Ling Wang ate only one meal a day to diet, held their breath before tying their belts, and leaned against the wall before they could stand up. After a year, the court officials all had dark complexions due to hunger. Why was this? Because the ruler liked it, the subjects could do it. In the past, King Goujian of Yue valued the bravery of his soldiers. When he trained his subjects, he first gathered them together, set fire to the ships, and tested his officers and soldiers by saying, "The treasures of the State of Yue are all on these ships." The King of Yue personally beat the drums to encourage his soldiers to advance. Hearing the drumbeats, the soldiers broke formation and rushed into the fire, and more than a hundred close ministers died. The King of Yue then sounded the retreat. Therefore, Mozi said: "Eating less, wearing poor clothes, and starving oneself to death for fame are all things that the common people of the world find difficult to do. If the ruler likes it, then the scholars can do it. How much more so for universal love and mutual benefit, which are different from these (good things). Those who love others will be loved by others in return; those who benefit others will be benefited by others in return; those who hate others will be hated by others in return; and those who harm others will be harmed by others in return. What is difficult about this universal love? It is only because those in superior positions do not use it in governing, and the scholars do not put it into practice."

instruction:
Here is the translation of the Chinese text:

"Ban Chao, courtesy name Zhongsheng, was a native of Pingling in Fufeng. He was the youngest son of Xu Lingbiao. Ban Chao was a man of great ambition who did not concern himself with trivial details. However, he was filial and conscientious. At home, he often undertook arduous tasks and did not shy away from menial labor. He had a silver tongue and was well-versed in the classics. In the fifth year of the Yongping era, his elder brother Ban Gu was summoned to serve as a proofreader, and Ban Chao accompanied their mother to Luoyang. Due to their family's poverty, he often worked as a scribe for officials to make a living. After enduring much hardship, he once put down his writing brush and sighed, saying, 'A man of valor has no other aspirations but to emulate Fu Jiezi and Zhang Qian, achieving merit in distant lands and earning a feudal title. How could he spend his life among ink and paper?' Those around him laughed at his words. Ban Chao replied, 'How could these youngsters understand the aspirations of a true man?'"
output: Ban Chao was a man with lofty ambitions who did not bother himself with trivial matters. However, he was filial and diligent at home, often enduring hardships and toil in his daily life, not considering labor as a disgrace. He was eloquent and well-versed, having perused many historical texts. In the year 62 AD (the fifth year of Yongping), his elder brother, Ban Gu, was summoned to serve as a proofreader, and Ban Chao accompanied his mother to Luoyang. Due to their family's poverty, Ban Chao often transcribed documents for the government to earn money and support his family. He endured prolonged transcription work, suffering great labor. Once, he stopped his work, threw down his brush, and exclaimed, "If a man does not have greater ambitions and strategies, he should still follow in the footsteps of Fu Jiezi during Emperor Zhao's reign or Zhang Qian during Emperor Wu's reign, achieving great feats in distant lands and earning the honor of a marquis. How can one remain confined to the world of brushes and inkstones for an extended period?" Those around him mocked him, to which Ban Chao replied, "How could a youngster understand the aspirations of a heroic man!"

instruction: Question: What were the main ideas of Confucius?
output: Answer: Confucius' main ideas included benevolence, righteousness, and filial piety, among others. He emphasized a people-oriented approach and advocated for harmony between individuals and society.

instruction:

What is the lithosphere in geology?
output: Answer: The lithosphere is the outermost thin layer of the Earth composed of rocks, including the crust and the upper part of the geosphere. It is the solid outer shell of the Earth's surface, comprising the land and the seabed crust.
