instruction:
In the ninth year of the Yonghe reign period, on the guichou day during the first month of spring, we gathered at the Orchid Pavilion in Shan Yin, at the Kuaiji Mountains, for a spring purification ceremony. Literati from far and wide, young and old, assembled here. This place is blessed with majestic mountains and lush forests of bamboo; clear streams and rushing rapids flow alongside, providing the setting for our floating wine cups and curving waterways, as we sit in orderly rows. Though we lack a grand ensemble of string and wind instruments, the combination of poetry and wine is enough for us to express our boundless emotions.

On this day, the sky is clear and the air is fresh, with gentle spring breezes blowing. We gaze upon the vastness of the universe above and contemplate the richness of creation below. Our eyes wander and our thoughts soar, as we indulge in the pleasures of sight and sound, and our hearts are filled with joy.

When people come together, they share a bond that spans a lifetime. Some find solace in their own hearts, understanding each other through unspoken words within closed rooms. Others seek to express their feelings by casting off the constraints of their physical selves and embracing a life of carefree wandering. Despite our diverse pursuits and temperaments—some seeking tranquility, others prone to restlessness—when we encounter something that delights us, we momentarily find contentment within ourselves, unaware of the encroaching hands of time. But when we have exhausted our pursuits and our passions begin to wane, our emotions change with the shifting circumstances. We look back on what once brought us joy, now but a distant memory, and still, our hearts stir with emotion. How much more so when we contemplate the fleeting nature of life, the inevitable end that awaits us all? As the ancients said, "The matter of life and death is indeed a weighty one." How sorrowful it is!

Whenever I peruse the writings of those who came before me and delve into the sources of their emotions, I find myself in harmony with their sentiments. I cannot help but sigh with emotion as I read their words, feeling a resonance deep within my heart. I understand that to regard life and death as illusory and to equate longevity with premature death are both foolish notions. Those who come after us will view our present time as we now view the past. Alas, how sorrowful! Therefore, I have compiled a list of the literati present on this occasion, recording their words and sentiments. Though the world may change and circumstances differ, the essence of our emotions remains the same. May those who read these words in the future also find resonance and inspiration in them.
output:
In the ninth year of Yonghe, in the Gui Chou year, during the first decade of March, we gathered in Lanting in Shan Yin City, Kuaiji County, for the purpose of performing the qingli ritual. Many wise and talented men have converged here, and the old and the young are gathered. Lanting is a place with towering peaks, lush and dense forests and bamboo groves; and clear and flowing streams, reflecting and surrounding the pavilion on both sides. We diverted the water to form a ring-shaped channel for floating wine cups, and sat by the winding stream, though without the grandeur of a full orchestra. But drinking and composing poems are enough to freely express the profound and hidden emotions.

On this day, the weather was clear and the breeze was gentle. Looking up, we surveyed the vast sky, and looking down, we observed the myriad things on the earth, stretching our eyes and broadening our minds, and indulging in the utmost pleasure of sight and sound, which was truly delightful.

People interact with each other and soon a lifetime passes. Some talk freely about their aspirations within the confines of a room; some find solace in the things they love, unfettered and unrestrained. Though each has their own pursuits, some seeking tranquility and others reveling in chaos, when they find joy in what they encounter, they feel a sense of contentment and satisfaction, oblivious to the impending aging. But when they grow weary of their beloved pursuits, their emotions change with their circumstances, and sighs ensue. Things once cherished become traces of the past in an instant, evoking sentiments that cannot be ignored, let alone the fleeting nature of life, ultimately culminating in obl. The ancients said, "Life and death are indeed momentous affairs." How can it not grieve people?

Whenever I contemplate the reasons for my predecessors' emotional stirrings, I find them resonating with my own sentiments. I cannot help but sigh with sorrow when facing their writings, though my heart cannot clearly explain why. I know that equating life and death is untrue, and claiming longevity is a fabrication. The way posterity views the present is akin to how the present views the past. Alas! Thus, I record the names of those present and the poems they composed. Though times may change and circumstances differ, the triggers of human emotions and the essence of their thoughts remain the same. Future readers will also find resonance in the poems and writings of this gathering.

班超字仲升，扶风平陵人，是徐令彪的小儿子。他志向远大，但不注重细节。他内心孝顺谨慎，在家经常从事艰苦的工作，不以劳动为耻。他口才好，涉猎广泛，读过很多书籍和传记。永平五年，哥哥班固被召去担任校书郎，班超和母亲一起随班固来到洛阳。由于家贫，班超经常为官府抄书来供养家人。长期的劳苦让班超一度放弃工作，扔下笔感叹道：“大丈夫若无其他志向，也应当效仿傅介子和张骞在异域立功，以此获得封侯，怎么能长期在书桌前辛劳呢？”身边的人都笑他。班超说：“小子怎么能懂得壮士的志向呢！”
output: Ban Chao was a man with lofty ambitions who did not bother himself with trivial matters. However, he was filial and diligent at home, often enduring hardships in his daily life and not considering labor as a disgrace. He was eloquent and well-versed, having perused many historical texts. In the year 62 AD (the fifth year of Yongping), his elder brother Ban Gu was summoned to serve as a proofreader, and Ban Chao accompanied his mother to Luoyang. Due to their family's poverty, Ban Chao often copied documents for the government to earn money and support his family. He endured prolonged periods of copying, enduring immense labor. Once, he put down his work, threw his brush, and sighed, "If a man does not have greater ambitions and strategies, he should still follow in the footsteps of Fu Jiezi during the reign of Emperor Zhao or Zhang Qian during the reign of Emperor Wu, achieving great feats in distant lands and earning the honor of a marquis. How can one remain confined to the world of brushes and inkstones for an extended period?" instruction:
Here is the translation:

Gao Feng, courtesy name Wentong, was from a family of farmers. His wife often went to the fields, spreading wheat in the courtyard, and asking Feng to watch the chickens. One day, there was a heavy rainstorm, and Feng, holding a pole and reciting a scripture, did not notice the floodwater carrying away the wheat. His wife returned and asked him what happened, and only then did he realize what had transpired.
output: Gāo Fèng, courtesy name Wēntōng, came from a family of farmers. His wife once went to work in the fields and spread the wheat out to dry in the courtyard while Gāo Fèng was left to watch over the chickens. It happened that a heavy rainstorm was falling, and Gāo Fèng, holding a bamboo pole, was reciting classical texts and did not realize that the rainwater had accumulated and was washing the wheat away. His wife returned and, surprised, asked him what had happened, and only then did Gāo Fèng come to his senses.

instruction:

What is Mexico's electoral system?
output: Answer: Mexico's electoral system is a majoritarian system, where the candidate who receives the most votes in each district is elected. The election of the Mexican president is through direct election, while the election of members of Congress and local government officials is through indirect election.

instruction: There are many shooting stars, but why are meteorites so rare?
output: Although hundreds of thousands of tons of meteoroids enter the Earth's atmosphere every year, very few fall to the ground in the form of meteorites. Seventy percent of the Earth's surface is covered by oceans, and there are also mountains, deserts, forests, and sparsely populated areas. As a result, very few meteorites and fragments can be picked up by people.

instruction:
Here is the translation of the Chinese text:

"(Chen) Wan-nian once fell ill and summoned Xian (Chen Wan-nian's son) to his bedside to teach and admonish him. The conversation lasted until midnight, and Xian fell asleep, his head touching the screen. Wan-nian flew into a rage and wanted to beat him, saying, 'When your grandfather was teaching and admonishing you, how dare you fall asleep and not listen to my words?' Xian bowed his head and apologized, saying, 'I fully understand what you have said, but the gist of it is that you want me to flatter you.' Wan-nian did not speak again."
output: Chen Wanian fell ill and called his son, Chen Xian, to his bedside to teach him how to read. He taught him until midnight, when Chen Xian began to nod off and his head hit the screen. Chen Wanian was very angry and wanted to beat him with a stick. He scolded him, saying, "I have been teaching you verbally, but you fell asleep and didn't listen to me. Why?" Chen Xian hurriedly knelt down and knocked his head on the floor, saying, "I know what you've been telling me, Father. instruction: Why do only bucks grow antlers?
output:
Apparently, during the mating season at the end of autumn and the beginning of winter, when the antlers of male elk are fully hardened, they exhibit particularly domineering behavior. Every morning at dawn, male elk run to higher ground to send out mating signals. Unpaired female elk then follow the sound, and once a male elk has taken in a female, she must wander with him.

If they encounter another mating group during their journey, the two male elk will engage in a duel, and the winner can take the losing male's group of females. Thus, strong male elk often have dozens of female elk. This shows that antlers are the weapon for male elk to compete with each other, while female elk do not need such equipment.

"Once, Qi Huan Gong went to visit a commoner scholar named Xiao Chen Ji, but he was unable to meet with him even after three attempts in one day. Qi Huan Gong replied, 'Not at all. A scholar who holds his status and wealth with pride would certainly look down on his ruler. And a ruler who boasts of his power and dominance would surely belittle his scholars. Even if this gentleman takes pride in his status and wealth, how can I, as a ruler, dare to act arrogantly as a hegemonic king?' After five attempts, he finally managed to meet with Xiao Chen Ji. Sure! Here is the translation:

instruction: What are the risks of artificial intelligence?
output:
Artificial intelligence, in a nutshell, is about machines doing things that require human intelligence, such as understanding languages, recognizing people or objects in photos, and driving cars. While artificial intelligence can bring about many contributions and benefits to humans, the potential risks associated with it are not unfounded.

The accuracy of artificial intelligence depends on the accuracy of the data it learns from. If the data is erroneous or biased, its inferences will also lack accuracy, leading to unpredictable consequences. These risks are even more pertinent if artificial intelligence is widely applied in fields like medicine and law. Furthermore, the misuse of artificial intelligence can lead to potential risks such as data breaches, loss of control over AI systems, reduction in employment opportunities, and ethical dilemmas.

instruction: What's the difference between a bedbug bite and a flea bite?
output:
Bedbugs are another tiny creature that feeds on human blood. Unlike fleas, bedbugs are only active at night. They hide in mattresses and carpets, and then bite people when they are asleep.

Unlike flea bites, which are most commonly found around the feet and ankles, bedbug bites occur on the upper body. You will see small, dark red spots on the face, neck, arms, and hands. Similar to flea bites, these spots usually appear in clusters or lines.

Bedbug bites are different from flea bites. Bedbug bites usually form red swellings or blisters, rather than small red bumps.

Bedbug bites are typically arranged in lines because bedbugs move along blood vessels when biting. These bite areas may experience intense pain and itching, and they usually occur on the upper body, such as the neck, waist, arms, and chest.

instruction:
Here is a simple translation of the classical Chinese text:

The Prime Minister of Qin, in his later years, held even greater power. He always had several soldiers, dressed in plain clothes and carrying clubs, standing outside his office. Whenever passersby paused to look or whisper to each other, the soldiers would immediately shout at them to stop. On one occasion, he took a day or two of sick leave, and the acting prime minister was left to handle matters alone. Out of fear, the acting prime minister dared not speak of anything else and only extolled the achievements and virtues of the Prime Minister, after which he immediately took his leave. The next day, when the acting prime minister entered the hall, the Prime Minister suddenly asked, "I heard you took a long time to report matters yesterday?" Terrified, the acting prime minister replied, "I only spoke of Your Excellency's merits and virtues, which are unparalleled in the world. I ended my speech and retired, and did not speak of anything else." The Prime Minister laughed and said, "Thank you very much!" It turned out that he had already instigated the officials in charge of reporting matters to submit a memorial, and as soon as the acting prime minister returned, a copy of the memorial had already arrived. He was so vindictive and petty.
output: The power and influence of Qin Hui grew even more formidable in his later years. Usually, there were several soldiers dressed in black and armed with clubs standing at the entrance of his residence. Anyone who dared to glance into the compound would be scolded. Once, when Qin Hui took a day or two off due to illness and did not attend the imperial court, the other minister in charge had to respond to the emperor alone. This minister dared not say anything about Qin Hui and could only continuously praise him in front of the emperor. The next day, when Qin Hui arrived for the morning court session, he suddenly asked the minister, "I heard you spoke for a long time in front of His Majesty yesterday?" The minister, fearful, replied, "I only praised your unparalleled virtues and then retired. I truly did not speak of anything else." Qin Hui laughed and said, "Thank you so much!" It turned out that he had already instigated officials to impeach the minister, and as soon as the latter returned home, a copy of the cabinet's impeachment was delivered to his residence. Such was the extent of Qin Hui's viciousness.

Then he would copy it again. He did this six or seven times before stopping. The part of his right hand that held the brush developed calluses. In the winter, when his hands would chap, he would soak them in hot water several times a day. Later, he named his study "Qi Lu (Seven Copies)."... Zhang Pu was adept at writing poetry and prose. When people from all over the place requested his writings, he would compose them on the spot in front of his guests. In no time at all, he would complete them, and as a result, his reputation soared for a time.
output: Zhang Pu loved to study when he was a child. He would definitely copy the books he read by hand. After finishing the copying, he would recite them and then burn the copies. Then he would copy them again. Only after six or seven times of this process would he stop. Calluses formed on the fingers and palms of his right hand where he held the pen. In winter, his skin would crack from the cold, so he soaked it in hot water several times a day. Later, he named his study "Qi Lu" (Seven Records)... Zhang Pu wrote poems and articles very quickly. When people from all over came to request them, he would not need to draft them but would complete them immediately in front of his guests. Because of this, Zhang Pu was very well-known at the time.

instruction: Why does the lotus flower "emerge from the mud unstained"?
output:
Lotus is one of the ten famous flowers in China. It is a perennial aquatic plant that can be divided into three major systems: oulen, zilian, and hualian. It "emerges from the mud without being sullied and is washed clean without being tainted".

In people's minds, the lotus is a symbol of nobility and purity. Then why can the lotus and its leaves "emerge from the mud without being sullied"? It turns out that their outer layers are covered with a waxy substance and are full of papilla-like protrusions. The spaces between the protrusions are filled with air, preventing the intrusion of muddy water. When their leaf and flower buds emerge from the mud, the waxy substance on their surface protects them, making it difficult for the mud to adhere. Even if a small amount of mud attaches to the leaf or flower bud, it is washed away by the rippling water. By the time they emerge above the water surface, they are naturally clean and beautiful.

instruction: Why can malachite be used to locate copper mines?
output: Apparently, the main chemical component of malachite is copper carbonate. When hydrochloric acid is dropped on it, it will bubble and sizzle. Malachite is brittle and fragile, with a relatively low hardness. It is usually the product of natural copper and chalcopyrite undergoing weathering after exposure to the surface. Therefore, where there is abundant malachite, it often indicates that there are more unweathered copper deposits underground.

instruction: Why add sugar to milk after boiling it?
output: Because milk contains lysine and white sugar contains fructose, and these two substances will form a compound -- fructoselysine -- under high temperatures of boiling. This substance can destroy the nutritional value of proteins, not only cannot be digested and utilized by the human body, but also can be harmful to it. The correct method is to not add sugar when heating milk, and you can add sugar after the milk has cooled down a bit.

instruction:
Here is the translation of the classical Chinese text:

"Fan Yang Zu Ti was a man of great ambition from a young age. He and Liu Kun both served as chief clerks of the provincial administration. They shared a bedroom, and one night, upon hearing a rooster crow in the middle of the night, Zu Ti kicked Liu Kun awake and said, 'This is not an unpleasant sound!' He then got up and danced. 

When they crossed the river, the Left Prime Minister Rui appointed him military advisor and master of ceremonies. While residing in Jingkou, Zu Ti gathered brave and able-bodied men and said to Rui, 'The disorder in the Jin dynasty is not because of an immoral ruler and resentful rebels but because of the conflict among the imperial clan, who tear each other apart, allowing barbarians to take advantage of the situation and spread their poison throughout the land. Now, the displaced people, having suffered from the calamity, yearn to take up arms themselves. Your Majesty, if you truly appoint a general to lead an army and put someone like me in charge of recovering the Central Plains, the heroes and talented individuals of the counties and commanderies will surely respond to your call!' 

Rui had never harbored any intention of campaigning in the north, but he appointed Zu Ti as General of Valiant Might and Governor of Yu Province. He provided him with provisions for a thousand men and three thousand bolts of cloth but no armor or weapons, and told him to recruit his own troops. Zu Ti led his clan's households, over a hundred of them, across the river. In the middle of the river, he struck the oar and swore, 'If I, Zu Ti, fail to pacify the Central Plains and return, may I be cast into this river!' He then stationed his troops in Huai Yin, set up foundries to cast weapons, and recruited over two thousand men before advancing further."
output:
In his early years, Fan Yang native Zu Ti already had great ambitions. He once served as the Chief Clerk of Si Province together with Liu Kun, with whom he also shared a bedroom. One night, upon hearing a rooster crowing, he kicked Liu Kun awake and said, "This is not a hateful sound." He then got up and danced with his sword. After crossing the river, the Left Prime Minister, Sima Rui, appointed him as a military consultant and Master of Sacrificial Ceremonies. 

Zu Ti, residing in Jingkou, gathered valiant and robust warriors and said to Sima Rui, "The turmoil in the Jin Dynasty is not because of a tyrannical ruler inciting resentment and rebellion among his subjects. Instead, it is the power struggle and mutual slaughter among the imperial kinsmen that have provided an opportunity for the Rongdi people to wreak havoc across the Central Plains. Now, the displaced people of Jin yearn to strengthen themselves, and Your Majesty truly has the capacity to dispatch generals with troops to restore the Central Plains, with people like me leading the army. Heroes and talented individuals from all over will surely respond to your call!" 

Sima Rui had never harbored any intention of northern conquest, but after hearing Zu Ti's words, he appointed Zu Ti as the General of Valiant Might and Governor of Yu Province. However, he only allocated provisions for a thousand people and three thousand bolts of fabric, without providing any weapons, leaving Zu Ti to figure out how to recruit and arm his troops. 

Zu Ti led his private army of over a hundred households across the Yangtze River. In the middle of the river, he struck the paddles against the boat and proclaimed, "If Zu Ti cannot bring peace and restoration to the Central Plains, then like the mighty river, he shall not return!" Thus, he set up camp in Huai'yin, built furnaces to smelt and forge weapons, recruited over two thousand more soldiers, and continued on his way.

Yan Yuan and Zi Lu were attending Confucius. Confucius said to them, "Why don't you each tell me your aspirations?" 

Zi Lu said, "I hope to be able to share my carriage, horses, clothing, and furs with my friends, and even if these things become worn out, I would have no regrets." 

Yan Yuan said, "I hope to not boast about my strengths nor to proclaim my accomplishments."

output: Emperor Taizong of Tang asked Wei Zheng, "Observing the emperors of recent times and antiquity, some have passed on the imperial position to the tenth generation, some to one or two generations, and some have gained and lost the world themselves. The reason why I often have worries is that I am afraid that I may not be able to find the appropriate methods to comfort and nurture the people, or that I may develop feelings of arrogance and laziness in my heart, allowing my happiness and anger to exceed the limits without realizing it. Can you describe this situation for me, so that I can take your words as a guideline?" Wei Zheng replied, "The feelings of love, desire, happiness, and anger are the same for both saints and ordinary people. Saints are able to control these emotions and not let them go beyond the limits, while ordinary people indulge them to the point of losing all sense of moderation... I hope Your Majesty can always exercise self-restraint to ensure that you possess the virtue of a good ending, so that future generations for eternity will depend on you."

instruction: Why is Kunming warm in winter and cool in summer?
output: Kunming is spring-like all year round. Even in winter, the temperature rarely dips below 7°C, and in summer, it rarely exceeds 20°C. Why is this? It turns out that Kunming's geographical location is uniquely advantageous. Although it is located near the tropics, the high altitude keeps the summers cool. In winter, the northern mountain ranges shield it from cold winds, while warm air currents from the south bring warmth, making winter feel like spring.

instruction:
Zong Que was named Yuan Gan, and he was from Nuye County, Nanyang. His uncle Bing was noble and did not serve in the government. When Que was still young, Bing asked him about his aspirations. Que replied, "I wish to ride the wind and break through ten thousand miles of waves." Bing said, "If you do not achieve wealth and honor, you will surely bring disaster to our family." 

When his older brother Mi took a wife, on her first night in their home, they were robbed. Que, at the age of fourteen, bravely confronted the robbers. There were more than ten of them, and they all fled with their hair and clothes in disarray, unable to enter the room. 

At that time, the world was at peace, and scholars focused on literature and the arts. Bing was known for his noble character, and all his sons and nephews, except Que, followed his example and were diligent students. However, Que was hot-tempered and fond of martial arts, so he was not well-regarded by his fellow townsfolk.
output: Zong Que, courtesy name Yuangan, was a native of Nuye County, Nanyang. His uncle, Zong Bing, was a learned man but refused to serve in the government. When Zong Que was still a child, Zong Bing asked him about his aspirations in life. The boy replied, "I wish to ride the mighty winds and scatter the endless waves that stretch for thousands of miles." (Zong Bing then said, "Even if you don't attain great wealth and honor, you will surely bring glory to your ancestors.") On the night of his elder brother Zong Mi's wedding, the celebration was raided by robbers. Despite being only 14 years old, Zong Que bravely fought against the robbers, scattering over a dozen of them and preventing them from entering the main hall. During those peaceful times, those with a reputation sought to pursue literary endeavors and achieve success through imperial examinations. Due to his profound knowledge, many followed Zong Bing in studying the Confucian classics. On the other hand, Zong Que, being headstrong and fond of martial arts, was not praised by his fellow townsfolk.

instruction: Dare not and cannot, which of these two words is it that one resolutely refuses to do out of fear?
output:
The terms "dare not do" and "cannot do" both indicate limitations in action, but they represent different meanings. 

"Dare not do" usually indicates an unwillingness to take action out of fear or a lack of confidence. In this case, people worry about risks and uncertainties and may experience psychological barriers and obstacles. For example, a person may want to learn a new skill but dare not try due to concerns about their performance or a fear of failure. 

In contrast, "cannot do" typically indicates an inability to take action due to objective conditions or constraints. Here, people have a certain awareness of their abilities or resources and thus acknowledge what they cannot do. For instance, an individual may want to take up a job that requires specific skills, but they cannot do so because they lack those skills. 

"Dare not do" and " "cannot do" are not absolute categories but rather relative states. Sometimes, people may experience both fear and inability towards a certain action, or they may become fearful because they cannot perform a certain task. Therefore, we need to analyze and judge each situation to determine the specific causes and limitations. 

Ultimately, addressing the issues of "dare not do" and "cannot do" requires different approaches and strategies depending on the context. If it is due to fear, one can gradually expand their comfort zone and take appropriate actions to boost confidence and courage. If it is due to objective constraints, one can explore alternative paths and methods to achieve their goals. In either case, it is essential to bravely face one's obstacles and actively seek solutions to fulfill one's goals and values.

instruction:
Here is a simple translation of the classical Chinese text:

Sun Wu [Sun Ce and Sun Quan] dominated Jiangzuo [the region south of the Yangtze River], competing with the Central Plains region. This was firmly established through the heroic strategies of Sun Ce and Sun Quan. However, the exceptional talents of that time, such as Zhou Yu, Lu Su, Lü Meng, and Lu Xun, were truly the pillars of the country, and their loyalty determined the survival of the state. Throughout history, generals have rarely been humble enough to acknowledge the superiority of others. Yet, these wise men were different. When Sun Quan first took charge, Lu Su wanted to return north, but Zhou Yu stopped him and recommended him to Sun Quan, saying, "Lu Su's talent is suitable for assisting the times. We should seek more talented individuals like him to achieve greatness." Later, as Zhou Yu was nearing his end, he wrote to Sun Quan, "Lu Su is loyal and courageous, never taking matters lightly. If you choose him to succeed me, my death will not be in vain." Thus, Lu Su succeeded Zhou Yu in leading the army. Lü Meng served as the magistrate of Xunyang, and when Lu Su met him, he said, "Your talent and wisdom today far surpass those of the past." He then paid respects to Lü Meng's mother, formed a friendship with him, and parted ways. Lü Meng eventually succeeded Lu Su. When Lü Meng was stationed at Lukou, he pretended to be ill and returned, Sun Quan asked, "Who can replace you?" Lü Meng replied, "Lu Xun has a profound mind and the talent to bear great responsibilities. Observing his plans and considerations, he is truly capable of taking on important duties, and there will be no more mistakes." So, Lu Xun succeeded Lü Meng. These four men succeeded each other, holding the western frontier for three to four decades, earning reputations as formidable generals. Cao Cao, Liu Bei, and Guan Yu were all thwarted by them. Although they recommended each other for their respective roles, Sun Quan entrusted them with all his heart, and this is why Wu became what it was, not by coincidence.
output: The reason why Sun Wu was able to possess Jiangdong and compete with the Central Plains was fundamentally due to the exceptional talent and grand strategy of Sun Ce and Sun Quan. At that time, among the brilliant talents of Eastern Wu (such as Zhou Yu, Lu Su, Lü Meng, and Lu Xun, who were known as the pillars of the state), there were ministers who were willing to share the fate of the country. However, since ancient times, most generals believed themselves to be virtuous and capable individuals, fearing that others might surpass them. But the virtuous individuals mentioned above were not like that. When Sun Quan had just assumed power, Lu Su (a northerner) wanted to go north to the Jiangbei region (to join Cao Cao). Zhou Yu stopped him and recommended him to Sun Quan, saying, "Lu Su's talent is suitable for assisting the ruler. We should seek more people like him to accomplish great undertakings." Later, when Zhou Yu was on his deathbed, he wrote a letter to Sun Quan, recommending, "Lu Su is loyal and valiant, and he never takes matters lightly. If you can use him to replace me, I will die without regrets!" Thus, Lu Su succeeded Zhou Yu in leading the army. Lü Meng served as the administrator of Xuning, and Lu Su met him and said, "Your current talent and wisdom are no longer the same as when you were a young boy in Wu (as Lü Meng had acquired a vast amount of knowledge by then)." Lu Su then paid respects to Lü Meng's mother, formed a friendship with him, and parted ways. Later, Lü Meng also replaced Lu Su in commanding the army. When Lü Meng was stationed at Lukou and fell ill, he requested to resign, and Sun Quan asked, "Who can replace you?" Lü Meng replied, "Lu Xun has profound wisdom and talent capable of bearing heavy responsibilities. Observing his strategic planning, I believe he can be entrusted with important tasks, and there will be no more mistakes." Thus, Lu Xun succeeded Lü Meng. These four individuals took turns leading the region for three to four decades, establishing their formidable reputation as renowned generals. Cao Cao, Liu Bei, and Guan Yu were all defeated by them at various times. Although they recommended each other, Sun Quan was also able to listen to them with an open mind. This is why Eastern Wu became a formidable force, and it was not a coincidence.

instruction: On the day Wuzi, the Emperor addressed his attendant officials, saying: "I have perused the Collected Works of Emperor Yang of the Sui Dynasty. The language is profound and extensive, and it is evident that he modeled himself on Yao and Shun, not Jie and Zhou. Yet, his actions were so contrary!" Wei Zheng replied: "Your Majesty, even a wise ruler should remain humble and receptive to the input of others. Thus, the intelligent offer their strategies, and the brave devote their strength. Emperor Yang, relying on his brilliance, became arrogant and self-reliant. Hence, he verbally espoused the principles of Yao and Shun, but in practice, he emulated the deeds of Jie and Zhou, never realizing his mistake until his empire's downfall." The Emperor remarked, "The past is not distant; it serves as our teacher!"
output: On this day of Xū-zǐ, the Emperor (Tang Taizong) said to the ministers standing beside him: "I have read the book *The Collection of Emperor Yang of Sui*, and I find the language profound and erudite. It is clear that it upholds Yao and Shun while condemning Jie and Zhou. But why did he, in practice, do the opposite?" Minister Wei Zheng replied: "Your Majesty, although all monarchs are wise and virtuous, they should remain open to counsel. Only then can the wise offer their talents and the brave exert their utmost efforts. Emperor Yang of Sui, however, relied on his position and was arrogant and self-righteous. Thus, despite espousing the virtues of Yao and Shun, his actions mirrored those of Jie and Zhou. Lacking self-awareness, he ultimately met his downfall." Hearing this, the Emperor was deeply moved and remarked, "The lessons of the past are not distant from us and should serve as a cautionary tale."

夫君子之行，静以修身，俭以养德。非淡泊无以明志，非宁静无以致远。夫学须静，才须学。非学无以广才，非志无以成学。淫猥浮漫，则不能励精；险险躁急，则不能治性。年与时驰，意与日去，遂成枯落，多不接世，悲守穷庐，将复何及！
output:
Here is the translation of the provided Chinese text:

Moral cultivation is a process of self-improvement, where one reflects through meditation to strive for perfection and practices frugality to cultivate noble virtues. Without purity of heart and few desires, one cannot have a clear and steadfast ambition. Without tranquility and calmness, one cannot achieve grand aspirations but only through long-term diligent study. To acquire true knowledge, one must engage in research and exploration with a peaceful body and mind, as talents are accumulated through continuous learning. Neglecting diligent study hinders the growth and development of one's talents. Lack of unwavering determination leads to academic failure. Indulgence in desires and a negative attitude hinder the motivation of the heart and spirit. Rashness, impatience, and anxiety impede the cultivation of one's temperament and integrity. If one squanders their youth and time, allowing their aspirations to wither, they will inevitably age like a fallen leaf, day by day. Such a person will not be of use to society nor contribute to it. Instead, they will be left with only sadness, confined to their destitute home, and by then, regret will be of no avail.

instruction:
Please answer the following questions:

What is the human digestive system, and which organs does it include? What are the functions of each organ?

**人体消化系统**

人体消化系统是一系列负责将食物转化为身体所需能量的器官。它包括以下器官：

- 口：进食食物并通过咀嚼和唾液开始消化过程。
- 食道：一张从口到胃的管子，通过蠕动将食物推向胃部。
- 胃：一个位于上腹部的器官，负责储存和继续消化食物，并释放胃酸以杀死细菌。
- 小肠：长约6米，是消化过程的主要部位。它负责吸收食物中的营养物质，包括葡萄糖、氨基酸和脂肪酸。
- 大肠：长约1.5米，负责吸收水分和电解质，并储存未消化的食物，形成粪便。
- 直肠：连接大肠和肛门的管道，负责储存粪便并通过排便将其排出体外。
- 肛门：位于直肠末端，是粪便排出的开口。

各器官的功能：

- 口：通过咀嚼将食物磨碎，并通过唾液中的酶开始消化碳水化合物。
- 食道：通过蠕动收缩将食物从口推向胃部。
- 胃：储存食物并通过胃酸和胃酶继续消化蛋白质和脂肪。
- 小肠：完成食物的消化过程，吸收营养物质，包括葡萄糖、氨基酸和脂肪酸。
- 大肠：吸收水分和电解质，并通过细菌发酵未消化的食物残渣，产生一些维生素和能量。
- 直肠：储存粪便并通过排便将其排出体外。
- 肛门：控制粪便的排出。
output:
Answer: The human digestive system is a system used to break down food, absorb nutrients, and eliminate waste. It includes organs such as the mouth, esophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine, and anus.

The functions of each organ are as follows:

Mouth: Responsible for chewing food and mixing it with saliva, initiating the digestion of starch and protein.

Esophagus: Transports chewed food to the stomach through peristaltic movements.

Stomach: Secretes stomach acid and enzymes to further break down food into an easily digestible form.

Small intestine: Absorbs most of the nutrients, including proteins, carbohydrates, fats, vitamins, and minerals.

Large intestine: Absorbs water and electrolytes, converting undigested food residue into solid feces.

Anus: Eliminates feces through the anus.

instruction:
Here is a simple translation of the text:

"Within my room, some books rest in boxes, some are displayed before me, and others are strewn about on my bed. Wherever I look, books are all I see. They are with me during my meals and daily activities, through sickness and pain, and in moments of sorrow, worry, anger, and lament. I may not notice the coming and going of guests and family members, nor the changing weather outside. Sometimes, I intend to get up, but the books, scattered like piles of dry branches, block my way. There are even times when I cannot move at all, and I laugh at myself, thinking, 'Is this not what I call my nest?' Then I invite guests to view my collection, and they, too, find it challenging to navigate. After entering, they struggle to leave, and we both laugh heartily, agreeing that it truly resembles a nest."
output: In my room, some books are piled on wooden boxes, some are on display in front, and some are on the bed. Whether I look up or down, books are everywhere around me. My daily routine, the moans when I am sick, and the feelings of sadness, worry, anger, and surprise—I experience all these with books. I don't receive visitors, nor do I meet my wife and children. I am also oblivious to the changes in the weather, be it windy, rainy, thundering, or hailing. Occasionally, I want to stand up, but the messy books surrounding me are like piles of dead branches, sometimes making it impossible for me to walk. So I laugh at myself and say, "Isn't this the book nest that I've mentioned?" Then I invite the guest to come closer and observe the situation at that moment. At first, the guest cannot enter the room, and even if they manage to get in, they cannot get out. So the guest also laughs and says, "This does indeed look like a bird's nest!"

instruction: Why might fog in the morning indicate a clear day?
output:
When there is more water vapor in the atmosphere, in the later half of the night or in the morning, as the temperature drops and the water vapor exceeds saturation, it condenses into tiny water droplets, forming fog near the ground. This kind of fog usually forms near high-pressure systems, and there are often no rain clouds near high-pressure systems.

As a result, sunlight can shine directly on the fog. The warm sunlight causes the small water droplets in the fog to evaporate, dispersing the fog and clearing the sky. This day is often sunny.

instruction: What is the story behind the Chinese idiom "Xū Niáng bàn lǎo"?
output: It is said that in ancient China, there was a beautiful woman named Xu Niang. She was very good at singing and dancing, and was beloved by the people. Once, Xu Niang traveled through a desolate mountain range to visit an ailing friend. Prolonged exposure to the elements aged her appearance. However, even in her middle age, her singing and dancing remained captivating, inspiring awe in all who witnessed it. Thus, the idiom "Xu Niang half-old" describes a woman who, though no longer young and showing some signs of aging, still retains her beauty and allure. This idiom is also used to describe a woman who takes good care of herself, appearing younger than her actual age, or a woman who still possesses a certain charm, especially in middle age and beyond.

instruction:
Here is my translation of the Chinese text:

"Duke Ping of Jin asked Master Kuang: 'I am seventy years old and wish to learn, but I fear that I am too old.' Master Kuang replied: 'Why not light a lamp?'' Duke Ping asked: 'Who would dare to be playful with their lord?' Master Kuang said: 'How could a blind servant dare to be playful with his lord? I have heard it said: One who loves to learn from a young age is like the morning sun rising; one who loves to learn in their prime is like the brilliant midday sun; and one who loves to learn in old age is like the light of a burning lamp. Is the light of a burning lamp not brighter than stumbling in the dark?'" Duke Ping replied: "Well said!"
output: Duke Ping of Jin asked Master Kuang, "I am seventy years old and want to learn. I am afraid it is too late." Master Kuang replied, "Why not light a candle and learn?" Ping Gong said, "Who is a subject that teases his king?" Master Kuang replied, "How dare I tease my monarch? I have heard: When one is young and fond of learning, it is like the sun's rays when it first rises; when one is in his prime and fond of learning, it is like the brightness at noon; when one is old and fond of learning, it is like lighting a candle in the dark. instruction:
Here is the translation of the classical Chinese text:

"Xu Cai He Yue, nicknamed Wei Zhai, once found more than 200 taels of silver while walking at night. He dared not mention it to his family, fearing that they would advise him to keep the money. The next morning, he took it to the place where he had found it. When a man came looking for it and described the amount of silver and the seal correctly, Wei Zhai returned it to him. The man wanted to give him a portion of the silver as a reward, but Wei Zhai said, 'If I find money and no one knows about it, it is still my property. Why would I be tempted by this small amount of silver?' The man thanked him and left.

On another occasion, Wei Zhai taught at the house of a eunuch, who had to go to the capital and left a box with Wei Zhai, saying that he would come to collect it another day. Several years passed without any news, and it was heard that the eunuch's nephew was coming south, but not to collect the box. Wei Zhai thus entrusted the box to him.

Indeed, Wei Zhai was just a poor scholar. It was admirable that he returned the silver, but what set him far apart from others was that he remained untouched by the allure of the gold in his care for several years."
output:
The scholar He Yue once picked up over 200 taels of silver while walking at night. He did not dare to tell his family about it, worrying that they would advise him to keep the silver. The next morning, he returned to the place where he had found the silver and saw a man searching for something. He asked the man about the amount of silver and the seal, and the man's answers matched. So, He Yue returned the silver to him. The man wanted to give him a portion of the silver as a token of gratitude, but He Yue said, "I picked up the silver, and no one else knows about it. All the silver could have been mine, so why would I be tempted by these few taels?" The man thanked him and left.

When He Yue was teaching at the home of an official, the official sometimes had to go to the capital and left a box with He Yue, containing hundreds of taels of silver. The official told He Yue to keep it safe and retrieve it when he returned. However, the official would be away for years at a time, with no news. When He Yue heard that the official's nephew was coming to the south for another matter, he entrusted the box to the nephew to return it to the official in the capital.

He Yue, a poor scholar, demonstrated his integrity by returning the silver he found. His resistance to temptation in the short term is commendable, but what is even more remarkable is that he did not give in to greed even though the official left the silver in his care for many years. His noble character far surpasses that of ordinary people!

instruction: Why do shrimp and crab turn red after being cooked?
output:
This is related to chemistry. It turns out that there is a kind of pigment that is bright red in the shells of these cooked shrimps and crabs. If you soak the red shells of shrimps and crabs in a chemical called acetone, this pigment will dye the acetone into a beautiful reddish-orange color, and the shells will also fade and turn pale. Later, someone isolated this pigment from lobster eggs, and it was named astaxanthin.

Animals containing astaxanthin are not only shrimps and crabs, but many crustaceans also use astaxanthin to adorn themselves. Some small-shell animals mainly contain chitosanase, and some crab species contain papilioerythrin. These pigments, including astaxanthin, have a structure similar to carotenoids, and they are widely distributed in nature. The chemical name is ketocarotenoid, and they are the main components of the pigments contained in animals such as "shrimp and crab generals".

The body color of living crustaceans varies due to differences in species and environment, but regardless of the body color of the living "shrimp and crab generals", as long as they are soaked in formaldehyde or heated, they will turn red. This is because the pigment protein in the biological body undergoes denaturation when heated, and the pigment originally bound to the protein "escapes", revealing the red color.

In addition, the death of shrimp and crab will also cause the change of protein in the body and the escape of pigment, making the shell turn red.

instruction:
Please answer the following question:

Question:
What is Indian Carnatic music, and what are its characteristics?

Answer:
印度卡纳达（Carnatic）音乐是一种起源于印度南部卡纳塔克邦和坦米尔纳德邦的古典音乐形式。它有着悠久的历史，可以追溯至数百年前。卡纳达音乐以其复杂性和细腻性而闻名，并具有以下几个特点：

1. 旋律丰富：卡纳达音乐拥有大量拉嘎（raga，印度古典音乐中的旋律模式）和丰富的旋律变化。每个拉嘎都具有独特的情感色彩，可以表达各种情感。

2. 节奏多样：卡纳达音乐采用复杂的节奏模式，称为塔拉（tala）。塔拉是由节拍循环组成的节奏体系，每首曲子都有特定的塔拉，使音乐充满了活力和变化。

3. 即兴表演：即兴表演是卡纳达音乐的重要组成部分。音乐家们在表演时根据特定拉嘎的框架即兴创作，展现他们的技巧和才华。

4. 重视唱腔：人声在卡纳达音乐中占有重要地位，歌手需要经过严格训练才能掌握复杂的音乐技巧和唱腔。

5. 乐器伴奏：典型的卡纳达乐器包括长笛、小提琴、手鼓、姆里丹格鼓（mrudangam）和威纳鼓（vina）等。这些乐器与人声相辅相成，营造出丰富多彩的音色。

6. 宗教与精神：卡纳达音乐与印度教有着密切的联系，许多歌曲以宗教和精神主题为基础。音乐被认为是一种通往精神世界的媒介。

总之，印度卡纳达音乐是一种复杂、细腻且充满表现力的音乐形式，它结合了丰富多变的旋律、复杂多样的节奏以及即兴表演，为人们带来了一场听觉盛宴。
output:
Answer:
Kannada music of India is a traditional form of music from the southern region of Karnataka in India. It is renowned for its unique melodic and rhythmic structure and is commonly sung in the Kannada language to express emotions, praise deities, and narrate stories.

instruction: What does the future hold for IAM?
output:
With remote work becoming the norm, the domain of identity and access management (IAM) has expanded greatly as mobile device usage hits its peak. Unsecure networks and unprecedented user expectations have led to a surge of new device connections and a constant stream of remote access requests for sensitive information, with the threat of phishing and other web-based attacks looming as users access rogue sites. 

Artificial Intelligence (AI) plays a crucial role in the future of IAM as it can recognize patterns and exponentially expand knowledge at the same pace as risks, by assessing user context with each interaction. 

Through continuous identity verification, AI can analyze micro-interactions while taking into account time, location, and even user mobility, calculating the potential risk level at each touchpoint. The evolution of next-generation antivirus software, host-based firewalls, and/or endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions will continue to enhance security within organizations.

instruction: How was the Earth formed?
output: 4.6 billion years ago, the proto-Earth began to differentiate within the solar nebula. It continued to accrete matter, increasing in volume. As the material inside the sphere warmed up and reached a molten state, the denser siderophile elements sank, forming the iron-nickel core. Lithophile elements composed the mantle and crust, and the liquid and gaseous components formed the primordial hydrosphere and atmosphere.

instruction: White cut chicken is a classic Cantonese dish. The chicken is first poached in a broth of ginger, scallions, and other spices, then cooled and cut into pieces. It is served with a dipping sauce made of soy sauce, ginger, and scallions. The dish is known for its delicate flavor and tender texture.
output:
Poached chicken is a traditional Chinese dish that is widely popular, especially in Guangdong and Singapore. The dish is characterized by its simple cooking method, yet it requires skill to achieve tender meat with a smooth and slippery skin texture.

The preparation of poached chicken mainly involves slowly cooking a whole chicken in boiling water and then rinsing it with cold water to tighten the skin and create a glossy texture. During the cooking process, spices such as ginger, scallion, and salt are usually added to enhance the flavor of the chicken.

Poached chicken is typically served with a dipping sauce made of ginger and garlic or soy sauce. In Singapore and Malaysia, poached chicken is often sold as "Hainanese Chicken Rice" along with chicken-fat rice, a popular street snack.

The key to delicious poached chicken lies in the selection of ingredients and the control of cooking temperature. The chicken should be fresh, preferably free-range or native chicken, and the cooking temperature must be just right to ensure that the meat is thoroughly cooked yet remains tender, resulting in a delicate and smooth texture.

Born in Jiangning, Nanjing, his ancestral home was Liaoyang. He came from a prestigious family of the Plain White Banner, under the administration of the Imperial Household Department. instruction: Why do Chinese people drive on the right?
output:
*On the Road in China*, written by an American, Peter Hessler, is about to become a bestseller. The copy I have in hand, published in April, is already the fourth edition. The total print run should be around 40,000 copies by now.

There are some interesting anecdotes in the book. For instance, why do Chinese people drive on the right side of the road?

In ancient times, when Chinese people drove carriages, they kept to the left, leaving the right side vacant. This practice was known as "keeping the left vacant." If China's traffic rules had evolved along this line, and if Shanghai's rickshaw pullers had become Ford drivers, they should have been speeding along the left side of the Huangpu River Bund.

However, in post-1945 China, the handful of Hummers and Ford cars surprisingly drove on the right side of the road. This practice of "right-hand drive" mirrored that of the Americans cruising on the interstate highways across the Great Plains. But why did we follow the American way?

The story goes back to the Anti-Japanese War. During that war, the relocated Chongqing government received assistance from numerous American soldiers. When the American troops drove in Chongqing, they kept to the right, while the local Chinese aristocrats stuck to the left. Accidents became frequent. Under strong pressure from the American military commander, Chiang Kai-shek issued an order for the entire country to adopt right-hand driving. And that's how we started driving on the right, just like the Americans.

instruction: The emperor, ascended the Cuiwei Palace, asked the attending ministers: "Since ancient times, emperors have been unable to subdue the Rong and Di nomads despite conquering Zhongxia. I, with less talent than the men of old, have achieved greater success, and I do not understand the reason for this. All of you, please speak your minds." The ministers all praised: "Your Majesty's grace is as vast as the heavens and the earth, beyond what words can describe." The emperor said: "Not so. The reason I have achieved this is solely due to five things. Since ancient times, emperors have often despised those better than themselves. I, however, see the goodness in others as if it were my own. As people cannot be perfect in every aspect, I always discard their shortcomings and embrace their strengths. Emperors often wish to favor the wise by keeping them close or get rid of the unworthy by pushing them away. I, on the other hand, respect the wise and empathize with the unworthy, ensuring that each finds their proper place. Emperors often dislike those who are upright and honest, punishing them in secret or executing them publicly. This has happened in every dynasty, but since I took the throne, upright and honest scholars have filled the court, and not one has been demoted or punished. Since ancient times, emperors have valued the Central Plains but looked down upon the barbarians and nomads. I, however, have loved them equally, and so their tribes have followed me as they would their parents. These five reasons are why I have achieved the success of today." Then he turned to Chu Suiliang and asked: "You have been a historian. Are my words true to the facts?" Chu replied: "Your Majesty's virtues are too numerous to be recorded. These five things you mentioned are but a humble expression of your greatness, reflecting your modest spirit."
output:
Tang Taizong was in the Cuiwei Palace and asked his attendant ministers: "Since ancient times, emperors have pacified the Central Plains and Hua Xia, but they have not been able to subjugate the ethnic minorities in the northwest. My talent is not superior to that of the ancient emperors, yet my achievements are greater than theirs. I don't know the reason for this. Please be frank." 

The ministers replied, "Your Majesty's grace is as vast as the heavens and the earth. There is nothing more to say about all other things." 

Tang Taizong said, "It cannot be said like that. The reason why I have such achievements is that I have only done five things: First, since ancient times, emperors have often been jealous of those who are better than themselves. When I see the strengths of others, I treat them as my own strengths and regard them as my own virtues. Second, everyone has their own strengths and weaknesses. I focus on their strengths and overlook their shortcomings. Third, most monarchs want to keep talented people close when they see their good side, but want to push them into the abyss when they see their bad side. However, when I encounter talented and virtuous people, I respect them, and when I encounter those who perform poorly, I educate them from a caring perspective. In this way, both the wise and the unwise find their proper place. Fourth, most monarchs dislike being criticized directly and often secretly harm or openly attack those who speak up. However, since I ascended the throne, there have been many who speak frankly, and not one of them has been dismissed because of their honest opinions. Fifth, traditionally, the Han ethnicity was considered superior, and discrimination against ethnic minorities was common. However, I have always treated everyone equally with care and respect, so the ethnic minorities rely on me as they would their parents. These five points are the reasons for my success today."

"Whenever Mr. Fan traveled, he brought along his books, loaded onto two horses and three mules. Whenever he arrived at a difficult or blocked passage, he would call for old soldiers or retired troops to inquire about the details. If the information they provided did not match what he had heard previously, he would immediately open his books in the marketplace and verify the facts. If he happened to forget something, he would open his books in the marketplace and review it thoroughly."
output: Whenever Gu Yanwu traveled, he would bring his books along, carried by horses or mules. Upon reaching treacherous terrain, he would dispatch retired messengers to scout ahead and report back on the conditions of the road. If he found discrepancies between the actual conditions and what he knew beforehand, he would proceed to the marketplace or inns, open his books, and verify the information. On occasions when the road was flat and uneventful, not worth stopping to investigate, he would silently recite on horseback the annotations and commentaries of various ancient classics. If there was something he had forgotten, he would retire to an inn, open his books, and review them carefully.

instruction: What is the XLSX file format?
output:
".XLSX" is the file extension for a spreadsheet file saved in the Microsoft Excel Open XML Format. It is a ZIP-compressed file that contains a spreadsheet created by Microsoft Excel 2007 or later, based on XML. 

An .XLSX file is used to store cell data and edits made within a worksheet, which is then stored within a spreadsheet (a file can contain multiple worksheets). Cells within a spreadsheet are located by their row and column positions and can contain styles, formats, mathematical functions, and more. 

Earlier versions of Excel spreadsheet files were saved in the .XLS format, while .XLSM files are Excel macro-enabled template files.

instruction:
Here is the translation of the Chinese text:

"(Yang) Zhen was fond of learning from a young age... When General Deng Zhi heard of his virtue, he invited him to join his administration and recommended him for the post of a Caomare talent. After four promotions, Zhen became the Governor of Jingzhou and the Magistrate of Donglai. On his way to take up the post in the commandery, he passed by Changyi, where Wang Mi, a Caomare talent he had previously recommended for Jingzhou, was now the magistrate. Wang Mi paid him a visit and at night tried to give him ten pounds of gold as a gift. Zhen asked, 'Do you recognize me, but I do not recognize you? Why is that?' Wang Mi replied, 'No one will know at this late hour.' Zhen said, 'Heaven knows, the gods know, I know, you know. How can you say no one will know?' Wang Mi felt ashamed and left. Zhen was later transferred to the position of Governor of Zhuo Commandery. He was known for his fairness and integrity, and he did not accept private visits. His descendants often ate vegetarian meals and walked instead of riding. Some of his old acquaintances wanted to help them develop their family business, but Zhen refused, saying, 'If future generations are known as the descendants of a clean and honest official, passing on this legacy to them would be a great honor, wouldn't it?'"
output: General Deng Zhi heard that Yang Zhen was wise and sent someone to recruit him, recommending him as a scholar. Yang Zhen was promoted several times and eventually became the Governor of Jingzhou and the Magistrate of Donglai. On his way to the county, he passed by Changyi, where Wang Mi, the Jingzhou scholar he had previously recommended, served as the county magistrate. Wang Mi came to pay his respects to Yang Zhen and, during the night, tried to offer him ten jin of silver secretly. Yang Zhen said, "I know you, but you don't know me. Why are you doing this?" Wang Mi replied, "No one will know at this hour." Yang Zhen said, "Heaven knows, the gods know, I know, and you know. How can you say no one will know?" Wang Mi left in shame. Later, Yang Zhen was transferred to Zhuo County as its magistrate. He was naturally just and honest, refusing to accept private visits. His descendants often ate vegetables and walked everywhere. One of his old friends, an elder, wanted to help his descendants set up some businesses, but Yang Zhen declined, saying, "Letting our descendants be known as the offspring of an honest official is a great gift in itself."

instruction:
Here is the translation of the classical Chinese text:

"In Jinxi county lived a commoner named Fang Zhongyong, whose family had long been tillers. When Zhongyong was five, he had never seen any books or writing utensils before. One day, he suddenly started crying and asking for them. His father found this strange, so he borrowed some from a neighbor and gave them to his son. Zhongyong immediately wrote a poem of four lines, even coming up with the title himself. The poem expressed sentiments of filial piety and unity among the clan, and it was passed around the village for all to admire. From then on, he could compose poems about any object he was shown, and his compositions always displayed a remarkable understanding of grammar and logic. The people of the county found this extraordinary, and some of them began to treat his father as an honored guest, or even offered him money. The father, seeing the benefits of this, spent his days bringing Zhongyong around the county to meet people and show off his talent, instead of sending him to school. I had heard of this story long ago. During the Mingdao era, I returned home with my father and saw Zhongyong at my uncle's house. He was twelve or thirteen at the time. I asked him to compose a poem, but it was not as impressive as the ones he wrote when he was younger. Seven years later, after returning from Yangzhou, I visited my uncle's house again and inquired about Zhongyong. My uncle replied, 'He has become an ordinary person, no different from the rest.'"
output:
Here is the translation of the Chinese text into English:

"In Jinxi County lived a commoner by the name of Fang Zhongyong, whose family had been farmers for generations. When Zhongyong turned five, he had never seen a brush, ink, paper, or inkstone before. One day, he suddenly started crying out loud, asking for these things. His father was astonished and borrowed them from a neighbor. Zhongyong immediately wrote a poem and signed his name. This poem, which was about supporting one's parents and uniting one's clan, was shown to all the scholars in the township. From then on, whenever he was given a topic, he could compose a poem on the spot, with both beautiful phrases and profound meanings. The locals were amazed by his talent, and some even treated his father as an honored guest or paid money to have Zhongyong write poems for them. His father, seeing this as an opportunity to profit, took Zhongyong around the county every day to visit people and did not let him study. I had heard about this story a long time ago. During the Mingdao era, when I returned to my hometown with my father, I saw Zhongyong at my uncle's house; he was twelve or thirteen years old at the time. When we asked him to compose a poem, it was no longer comparable to his previous reputation. Seven years later, when I returned from Yangzhou and visited my uncle again, I inquired about Zhongyong's situation. The reply was: 'His talent has completely vanished, and he has become an ordinary person.'"

instruction: Why do I always lose when playing the "slot machine"?
output:
I believe many people have had the experience of playing slot machines. Some people gamble in moderation and know when to stop. These people are fortunate. However, many others find themselves unable to resist the lure of the machines and end up losing everything, including their homes and life savings. Some even end up in debt to loan sharks, losing their families and everything they hold dear. So, we must ask, why do people always lose when they play slot machines? In the following paragraphs, I will analyze this problem through mathematics and human nature.

In theory, the odds of winning and losing on a slot machine are fairly balanced. So, why is it that we always seem to lose? Let's take a common payout ratio of 6, 6, 8, 8, 8, 8, 12, 12 as an example. Firstly, the payout ratios are set fairly. It is easy to verify that 1/6 + 1/6 + 1/8 + 1/8 + 1/8 + 1/8 + 1/12 + 1/12 = 1. Secondly, the program is preset, which means that whether you bet 10 or 1,000 credits, the odds of winning remain the same for that particular game. So, where is the problem?

Firstly, we lose because we lack common sense in judgment. While the program may be designed to provide fair odds, it is still created by someone and is not randomly generated. Players often encounter programs like this: a rabbit (with a payout of 6) appears four or five times in a row. What does this mean? The probability of the rabbit appearing once is 1/6, and the theoretical probability of it appearing five times in a row is 1/7776. If we assume that a game takes one minute and there are 60 games played per hour, then in a 24-hour day, this situation should theoretically occur once every 5.4 days. However, in reality, we often encounter it three or four times in a single day, which is clearly illogical. The reason lies in the human factor of the design.

For example, let's say I decide to bet on an eagle (with a payout of 12). Theoretically, the eagle should appear once every 12 games on average. However, it is entirely possible that it won't appear for 32 consecutive games (about half an hour), and if you keep betting during this time, you could lose all your capital and have no chance to recoup your losses. Let's calculate the theoretical probability of the eagle not appearing for 32 consecutive games: the probability of it not appearing in one game is 11/12, and the probability of it not appearing in 32 games is (11/12)^32, which is approximately 6%. In mathematics, we refer to probabilities smaller than 5% as small probability events, meaning they are almost certain not to occur. In this case, the probability is very close to this threshold, yet this situation occurs frequently in reality.

Secondly, we lose because of our own greed. Many people have had the experience of initially winning when they start playing, but instead of walking away, they continue playing, wanting to win more. They keep playing until they encounter a program like the one mentioned above, and even then, they refuse to accept that they are beat and continue to chase their losses. Eventually, they lose everything, including their original capital and any winnings. After each loss, they tell themselves that next time, they will only win a certain amount and then stop, but how many people can actually do this? If you bring $10,000 and aim to win $1,000, it is relatively achievable, and with persistence, you could still earn $30,000 per month. However, in reality, if you bring $10,000, you likely want to win $10,000, and this excessive greed eventually leads to losing everything.

Therefore, I would like to advise everyone to value their lives and stay away from electronic heroin. It's not too late to turn back now!

instruction: Why does a snail leave a wet trail as it crawls?
output:
Snails have very soft bodies and are afraid of hard objects on the ground that may cause damage. Therefore, when they crawl, they secrete a slippery mucus from their foot glands to reduce friction between their feet and the ground. This also facilitates the quick movement of their feet.

As a result, snails always leave a shiny, wet mark on the ground after they pass by.

(Tang Dynasty) Emperor Taizong said to his attendants: "In the past, when the capital was first pacified, the palace was filled with beautiful women and precious treasures, with no room left empty. Emperor Yang of Sui still felt it was not enough, ceaselessly seeking more, while also waging campaigns to the east and west, exhausting the military and engaging in reckless warmongering. As a result, we have avoided conscription, enjoyed bountiful harvests, and the people have lived in happiness. instruction: Question: What is the most common sport?
output: Answer: In our daily lives, the most common types of exercise we do are aerobic exercise, strength training, and flexibility training. Aerobic exercise mainly improves and enhances the body's aerobic working capacity. This category of exercise includes walking (strolling, brisk walking, quantitative walking, walking with a cane, and racewalking), jogging (or fitness running), alternating between walking and running, cycling, running on a treadmill, aerobic dancing, calisthenics, and non-intense ball sports, etc. Strength training is a type of exercise that focuses on increasing strength and body shaping. Examples include using dumbbells, barbells, springs, and rubber bands for weight-bearing or resistance exercises, which help prevent and treat osteoporosis. Flexibility training involves lengthening muscles and ligaments while also regulating breathing rhythms. Examples include yoga, medical gymnastics, and various types of health-preserving qigong, etc. Whether it's before aerobic or strength exercises as a warm-up or after as a cool-down, flexibility training is an indispensable part of the routine.

At the outbreak of the Pacific War, the destroyer "Ikazuchi" was assigned to the 6th Destroyer Division, along with the destroyers "Akatsuki," "Hibiki," and "Inazuma," under the 1st Torpedo Squadron. On December 4, 1941 (Showa 16), it participated in the Battle of Hong Kong, and together with "Inazuma," they sank a British gunboat with their main batteries. However, on December 20, as the two ships approached Hong Kong Island, they came under fire from the 9.2-inch coastal defense guns of the Stanley Fortress. A shell fell 10 meters away from the ship, causing minor damage, and as neither ship could return fire, they laid smoke and withdrew. On January 9, 1942 (Showa 17), it took part in the Battle of Manado. On March 1, during the Battle of the Java Sea, along with the heavy cruisers "Ashigara," "Myoko," "Nachi," and "Haguro," and the destroyers "Yamakaze" and "Kawakaze," they sank the British heavy cruiser HMS Exeter, the destroyer HMS Encounter, and the US destroyer USS Pope. On March 2, under the command of Destroyer Captain Toshisaku Kudo (Navy Lieutenant Commander), the crew of "Ikazuchi" rescued 422 surviving crew members from the sunk HMS Encounter and USS Pope. The destroyer "Inazuma" also provided assistance in the rescue operation, and eventually, the survivors were handed over to a Dutch hospital ship. On May 2, it was reassigned to the Northern Force, and on the 29th, it set sail from the Riutsu Bay in Kawauchi, heading for the Aleutian operation.

instruction: Why can we see things at night using infrared?
output: Any hot object—as long as it is not at absolute zero—can radiate this kind of invisible infrared radiation. The most obvious effect of infrared radiation on an object is to generate heat. In the winter, when you are warming yourself by a red-hot stove, it is because a large amount of infrared radiation is emitted from the stove to your body, and you feel warm. The wavelength of infrared radiation is longer than that of all visible light, so it seems to have a convenient leg that can almost bypass all obstacles on its path and pass through even heavy fog. When an enemy plane flies into our position, an infrared telescope has already received a large amount of infrared radiation emitted by its heat-generating part—the engine. The infrared radiation generates a current in the "photoelectric converter" of the telescope, and then the current generates visible light. Thus, the plane in the dark is revealed in the mirror.

instruction: Why do earthquakes happen?
output:
An earthquake is just like a storm or rain; it is a very common natural phenomenon.

The vast majority of earthquakes are caused by crustal movements. During these movements, hard rocks are subjected to forces that cause them to change shape, sometimes breaking, which is when an earthquake occurs. Although scientists still debate the source of the forces that drive crustal movements and there are many speculations about the fundamental causes of earthquakes, there is no doubt that the direct cause of an earthquake is the breaking of rocks in a particular location. The vast majority of earthquakes occur when new fractures form in underground rocks or when pre-existing cracks slip again. Many strong earthquakes occur where there are fractures underground. When the forces acting on underground rocks approach the point of breakage, the gravitational pull of the sun and moon, and changes in atmospheric or water (reservoir) pressure on the ground, can all contribute to the breakage, potentially triggering an earthquake.

Additionally, earthquakes often accompany volcanic eruptions. There are many volcanoes on Earth, and each time one erupts, a large amount of scorching magma surges from underground, rapidly expanding in volume and impacting the crust, inevitably causing an earthquake.

instruction:
Answer: Artificial intelligence has a wide range of applications in smart home security. 

Here are some examples: 

- **Face Recognition**: AI-powered face recognition technology can be used to identify family members and authorized individuals, granting them access to the home. This can be integrated with a smart lock system, allowing keyless entry and enhancing security. 

- **Intruder Detection**: AI can analyze data from motion sensors, cameras, and other devices to detect intruders. By learning the patterns of regular activities within the home, AI systems can identify unusual behavior and alert homeowners or authorities. 

- **Smart Alarms**: AI-enabled alarms can distinguish between different types of threats, such as fire, gas leaks, or unauthorized access. They can also learn the patterns of a homeowner's daily routine and send alerts if something deviates from the norm, indicating a potential security risk. 

- **Data Analytics**: AI can analyze large volumes of data from various sensors and devices within the smart home ecosystem. This data analysis can identify potential vulnerabilities, predict maintenance needs, and optimize the overall security system. 

- **Natural Language Processing**: NLP enables AI systems to understand and respond to voice commands, allowing homeowners to control lighting, temperature, and other smart devices using natural language. This enhances convenience and security, especially in situations where manual interaction is not feasible. 

- **Behavioral Analytics**: By studying the behavior patterns of occupants, AI can identify potential security risks. For example, if an elderly person's daily routine changes significantly, it could indicate a health issue or the presence of an intruder. AI can detect such anomalies and trigger appropriate responses. 

The applications of AI in smart home security offer enhanced protection, convenience, and peace of mind for homeowners. As AI technology continues to evolve, we can expect even more innovative and effective security solutions in the future.
output: Answer: The applications of artificial intelligence in smart home security include intrusion detection, smart door locks, smart alarms, and so on.

instruction:
Translation of the ancient Chinese text:

The Emperor held a banquet at the Southern Palace in Luoyang and asked, "My lords and generals, none of you shall hide the truth from me. Tell me, how was it that I came to possess the empire, and how was it that Xiang Yu lost it?"

Gao Qi and Wang Ling replied, "Your Majesty ordered your men to attack and occupy cities and then rewarded them accordingly, sharing the benefits with the world. Xiang Yu did not do this. He harmed those who achieved merit and doubted the virtuous. This is why he lost the empire."

The Emperor said, "You know one reason, but not the other. In planning military strategy within the confines of the tent, and deciding the outcome of battles from afar, I am not as good as Lord Zifang (Zhang Liang). In stabilizing the nation, comforting the common people, providing provisions and ensuring the supply lines remain uninterrupted, I am not as good as Xiao He. In leading an army of millions, ensuring victory in battle and success in attack, I am not as good as Han Xin. These three men are all exceptional, and I was able to employ them. This is how I gained the empire. Xiang Yu had Fan Zeng but failed to make use of him. This is why he was captured by me."
output: Liu Bang held a banquet at the South Palace in Luoyang and said, "Kings, princes, and generals, do not hide it from me. Tell me the truth: Why was I able to gain the world, and why did Xiang Yu lose it?" Gao Qi, Wang Ling, replied, "Your Majesty attacks and takes cities, gaining land and using it to win over others, aligning your interests with those of the world. Xiang Yu, on the other hand, did not do this. He killed those with merit and doubted those with talent. This is why he lost the world." Liu Bang said, "You only know one side and not the other. (Take, for example) the planning of strategies within the tent and deciding victory from a thousand miles away—in this, I am not better than Zhang Liang. In pacifying the nation, comforting the common people, providing military rations, and ensuring the constant supply of grain, I am not better than Xiao He. In uniting the soldiers and achieving certain victory in battle, I am not better than Han Xin. These three men are heroes, and I was able to make use of their talents, which is why I gained the world. Xiang Yu had Fan Zeng but did not utilize him, and that is why I was able to capture him."

instruction:
Here is a simple translation of the classical Chinese text:

There was a man living near the border who was skilled in the occult. One day, his horse ran away and entered the territory of the Hu people. Everyone offered their condolences, but his father said, "Why should this not be a blessing?" After a few months, the horse returned with a fine Hu steed. Everyone congratulated him, but his father said, "Why should this not be a calamity?" The family became wealthy from the horses, and his son enjoyed riding them. However, one day he fell off a horse and broke his hip. Everyone offered their condolences once more, but the father said, "Why should this not be a blessing?" A year later, the Hu people launched a major invasion across the border, and all the able-bodied men took up arms to fight. Nineteen out of every twenty men living near the border were killed. The man with the broken hip and his father were the only ones in their family to survive, precisely because of his injury.
output: There was an old man living near the border whose horse ran off into the territory of the Hu people for no reason. The neighbors all came to慰问 (express sympathy to) him. The old man said, "Why can't this turn into a good thing? Several months later, the horse returned with a fine horse from the Hu people. The neighbors all came to congratulate his family. The old man said, "Why can't this turn into a bad thing? He had many fine horses, and his son loved to ride them. One day, he fell off a horse and fractured his thigh. People came to慰问 (comfort) his family. The old man said, "Why can't this turn into a good thing? A year later, the Hu people launched a massive invasion of the border areas, and the able-bodied men took up bows and arrows to fight. Most of the people living near the border were killed. Only this man was spared from the draft because of his injured leg, and so father and son were able to survive. Thus, fortune can turn into misfortune, and misfortune into fortune, in ways that are impossible to predict or fathom.
